Acacia rostellifera low forest with scattered Eucalyptus camaldulensis on Greenough Alluvial Flats
EC_DESC:
Acacia rostellifera low forest with scattered Eucalyptus camaldulensis on Greenough Alluvial Flats (Beard 1976).
2 sub-communities: (1) Front Flats -  Acacia rostellifera thickets with Melaleuca sp. and scattered Eucalyptus camaldulensis on Greenough alluvial flats; and
(2) Back Flats - Acacia rostellifera thickets with scattered Eucalyptus camaldulensis, E. loxophleba and Banksia scrub on Greenough alluvial flats.

Herbaceous plant assemblages on bentonite lakes
EC_DESC: The plant community comprises herbaceous plant assemblages dominated by a combination of Triglochin mucronata, Trichanthodium exile, Asteridea athrixioides and Puccinellia stricta (Vegetation types 1,2,3&7) on the lake beds and Podolepis capillaris, Angianthus tomentosus and Pogonolepis stricta (Vegetation types 4,5&6) on the lake margins of bentonite playa lakes in the Watheroo region. This herbaceous plant community is characterised by a dependence on a bentonite substrate restricted to the ephemeral freshwater bentonite playas of the Watheroo region on the Dandaragan Plateau. The component species are found elsewhere in Western Australia within and around brackish and saline wetlands; but they were only found in combination dominating the fresh water bentonite-based wetlands.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Ferricrete floristic community (Rocky Springs type)
EC_DESC: Tall shrubland on seasonally inundated red brown sandy loams over ironstone dominated by Dryandra stricta, Allocasuarina campestris, Labichea lanceolata and Acacia blakelyi on the Eneabba Plain. It also comprises a rich herbaceous layer. This tall shrubland is located on irregularly inundated red brown sandy loams over ferricrete dominated by Acacia blakelyi, Allocasuarina campestris, Dryandra stricta and Labichea lanceolata subsp. lanceolata. Associated species include Alyogyne hakeifolia, Borya sphaerocephala, Isotoma hypocrateriformis, Petrophile seminuda, Stylidium dichotomum, Thysanotus patersonii and Pterochaeta paniculata. Ferricrete substrate is extremely restricted in distribution in the Eneabba region. It is thought, however, that the community is naturally restricted to the ferricrete substrate and possibly only a few occurrences ever existed. There are only two known occurrences of this community. These occur on the Eneabba Plain in the Shire of Carnamah, and just east of the edge of the Dandaragan Plateau in the Shire of Three Springs.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Ferricrete floristic community (Rocky Springs type)
Ferricrete floristic community (Rocky Springs type)
Assemblages of organic mound springs of the Three Springs area
EC_DESC:
The habitat of this community is characterised by continuous discharge of groundwater in raised areas of peat.  The peat and surrounds provide a stable, permanently moist series of micro habitats. There is a high level of heterogeneity of invertebrate fauna assemblages between these sites, and all are associated with a rich and healthy fauna.  Results of a survey of a subset of the springs are documented in Pinder and Pennifold (2001) who concluded that “although it is unlikely that any element of this subset is restricted to these particular springs, taken together they form an assemblage that may not occur in other aquatic habitats”.

The plant assemblages associated with these organic mound springs comprise an overstorey of Melaleuca preissiana trees sometimes in combination with Eucalyptus camaldulensis and/or Eucalyptus rudis; the shrubs Hypocalymma angustifolium, Acacia sp.; sedges of Baumea vaginalis; and herbaceous species including Patersonia occidentalis

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Ethel Gorge aquifer stygobiont community
EC_DESC: The Ethel Gorge/Ophthalmia Basin alluvium calcrete aquifer occurs on the Fortescue River in the vicinity of the town of Newman and contains an interesting assemblage of stygofaunal species.  This stygofaunal assemblage includes Oligochaeta and the crustaceans Bathynellacea (Syncarida), cyclopoid and harpacticoid copepods, Candonidae: Candoninae C (Ostracoda: Podocopida), Candonidae: Candoninae D (Ostracoda: Podocopida), Limnocytheridae (Ostracoda: Podocopida), flabelliferan Isopod “Tainisopodidae”) and one new genus of Crangonyctoid amphipoda (Chydeakata), in which fourteen species (thirteen in this aquifer) have been described on morphological characters (Bradbury 2000). Genetic and morphological results are discordant, but at least one species of Chydaekata is known only from this community based on both morphological and genetic characters. Species within Chydaekata are all of the family Paramelitidae, the largest family of Australian inland amphipods. Australian Crangonyctoid amphipoda are ancient fauna, probably predating the break up of Pangaea, and are bound to regions that have not been inundated by the sea since the Cretaceous.  The fact that these stygofauna are restricted to permanent fresh underground waters in the arid region, is presumed to be either as the result of being driven into refugia by climatic deterioration, or being the relict survivors of a once more extensive fauna (Bradbury 2000).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Ethel Gorge aquifer stygobiont community
EC_DESC: The Ethel Gorge/Ophthalmia Basin alluvium calcrete aquifer occurs on the Fortescue River in the vicinity of the town of Newman and contains an interesting assemblage of stygofaunal species.  This stygofaunal assemblage includes Oligochaeta and the crustaceans Bathynellacea (Syncarida), cyclopoid and harpacticoid copepods, Candonidae: Candoninae C (Ostracoda: Podocopida), Candonidae: Candoninae D (Ostracoda: Podocopida), Limnocytheridae (Ostracoda: Podocopida), flabelliferan Isopod “Tainisopodidae”) and one new genus of Crangonyctoid amphipoda (Chydeakata), in which fourteen species (thirteen in this aquifer) have been described on morphological characters (Bradbury 2000). Genetic and morphological results are discordant, but at least one species of Chydaekata is known only from this community based on both morphological and genetic characters. Species within Chydaekata are all of the family Paramelitidae, the largest family of Australian inland amphipods. Australian Crangonyctoid amphipoda are ancient fauna, probably predating the break up of Pangaea, and are bound to regions that have not been inundated by the sea since the Cretaceous.  The fact that these stygofauna are restricted to permanent fresh underground waters in the arid region, is presumed to be either as the result of being driven into refugia by climatic deterioration, or being the relict survivors of a once more extensive fauna (Bradbury 2000).

Russell Range mixed thicket vegetation complexes
EC_DESC: Mixed thicket vegetation complexes in the Russell Range System, as per Beard (1973).  Barrett (1996) described the vegetation of Mt Ragged, which occurs within the Russell Range System, as follows: Open mallee/shrub mallee-heath on the mid to upper slopes.  Typical species are Eucalyptus doratoxylon, Adenanthos oreophilus, Dampiera parvifolia, Monotoca oligarrhenoides, and the endemics: Dryandra longifolia ssp. archeos, Phebalium rude ssp. lineare and Scaevola brookeana.  Darwinia sp. Mt Ragged is also endemic to the mountain.  Priority taxa include: Leucopogon apiculatus and Chorizema nervosum.  Kennedia beckiana (Declared Rare) occurs mainly on the mid-lower slopes.  Anthocercis viscosa, common on granite on the south coast from Walpole to Cape Arid, occurs at its inland or eastern limit on Mt Ragged.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Montane Thicket of the eastern Stirling Range
EC_DESC: Montane Thicket and Heath of the South West Botanical Province, above approximately 900m above sea level. In the eastern Stirling Range a montane community distinct from that occurring in the central and western Stirling Range is found at high altitudes. The community structure is or was typically that of a dense heath or thicket with scrub vegetation on skeletal soils. Factors affecting plant growth include low temperatures and high wind speeds that prevail for much of the year. A key species indicative of its distribution is Andersonia axilliflora, which is or was an abundant and dominant member of the community. Using A. axilliflora as an indicator, the community extends from the eastern limit of the Stirling Range, Ellen Peak, more or less continuously at high altitudes to Coyanarup Peak, with a separate occurrence on the summit area of Mt Success. Other species that characterise the community include Kunzea montana, Beaufortia anisandra, Sphenotoma sp. Stirling Range, Andersonia echinocephala and Darwinia spp. A range of proteaceous species were or are structurally significant and include Banksia oreophila, Banksia solandri, Banksia brownii and Dryandra concinna.

Shrublands on southern Swan Coastal Plain Ironstones (Busselton area)
EC_DESC: This species-rich plant community is located on seasonal wetlands on ironstone and heavy clay soils on the Swan Coastal Plain near Busselton. Much of the species diversity comes from annuals and geophytes. Typical and common native species are the shrubs Kunzea aff. micrantha (B.J.Keighery and N.Gibson 040), Pericalymma ellipticum, Hakea sp. Williamson (B.J.Keighery and N.Gibson 226), Hemiandra pungens and Viminaria juncea, and the herbs Aphelia cyperoides and Centrolepis aristata. Many taxa in the community are highly restricted in distribution, dieback susceptible and/or are obligate seeders. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 10b’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

Mount Lindesay - Little Lindesay Vegetation Complex
EC_DESC: E. marginata shrub-mallee and heath predominates on the upper slopes and summit area with mixed E. marginata – E. calophylla – E. megacarpa low woodland in gullies.  Soils are shallow or skeletal.  In these areas, typical (occurring in more than 60% of quadrats) shrub species include Banksia grandis, Hakea varia and Beaufortia decussata, and typical sedges are Mesomelaena gracilipes and Tetraria capillaris. Priority taxa on the upper slopes and summit area include: Sphenotoma parviflorum, Gastrolobium brownii and Sollya drummondii.  Andersonia sp. Mt Lindesay, which occurs on the lower slopes, and Andersonia aff. setifolia are endemic to Mt Lindesay and Little Lindesay.  Relatively bare granite rock slabs dominate the middle slopes and support a unique community of scrub and open herbs, which includes a number of species endemic to Mt Lindesay and Little Lindesay.  These include: Borya longiscapa, Grevillea fuscolutea, Lasiopetalum aff. cordifolium, Cryptandra congesta and an undescribed species of Laxmannia.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Calothamnus graniticus heaths on south west coastal granites
EC_DESC: This vegetation type occurs on granulite outcrops (an exposed metamorphic rock) in localised patches. It occurs as strips parallel to and in close proximity to, the coast, in between boulders on exposed upper granulitic slopes, usually near headlands. The dominant, Calothamnus graniticus subsp. graniticus is a shrub varying from approximately 1.2-2.0 metres tall and is often wind-pruned as it grows to within 15m of the shore. The dark green colour of the Calothamnus and the granite boulders give a distinctive appearance to the community. Other prominent shrub species are Dodonaea ceratocarpa, Spyridium globulosum, Hakea trifurcata, Viminaria juncea, Acacia pulchella, Thryptomene saxicola, Melaleuca systena and Xanthorrhoea preissii. Smaller shrubs include Darwinia citriodora, Pimelea angustifolia, Pimelea ferruginea, Hibbertia hypericoides, Hibbertia cunninghamii, Phyllanthus calycinus and Cryptandra arbutiflora. The herb layer is diverse and includes Conostylis setigera, Lomandra nigricans, Haemodorum laxum, Haemodorum simplex, Caladenia latifolia, Caladenia longicauda, Desmocladus fasciculatus, Drosera menziesii, Drosera erythrorhiza, Laxmannia sessiliflora, Kennedia prostrata (red runner) and the ferns Cheilanthes austrotenuifolia and Cheilanthes sp.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Rimstone Pools and Cave Structures Formed by Microbial Activity on Marine Shorelines
EC_DESC: The term microbialites has been used to describe structures produced through the growth and metabolic activity of benthic microbial communities. It encompasses stromatolites, thrombolites, tufa, travetines, algal nodules and algal biscuits. Tufa is commonly applied to those structures with less defined internal framework that are precipitated from freshwater springs and seeps and is the type of microbialite structure common to this threatened ecological community. Spectacular tufa formations have been described along the south coast near Augusta. The tufa appear in many forms including drapes, curtains, small cylindrical stalactites and larger campanulate masses on the sea cliffs, as well as fans or terraces consisting of a series of rimstone pools and nodular masses in small brackish pools.

Scott River Ironstone Association
EC_DESC: This community is a winter-wet shrubland that occurs on skeletal soils over massive ironstone on the Scott Coastal Plain. The ironstone soils are extremely restricted in distribution and are believed to have been formed by the precipitation of iron from groundwater. Heath and shrublands are variously dominated by Melaleuca preissiana, Hakea tuberculata, Kunzea micrantha or Melaleuca incana subsp. Gingilup depending on the degree of waterlogging. The understory is generally dominated by Loxocarya magna. All occurrences except the long inundated wetlands and dense thickets have very diverse annual flora of Stylidium spp., Centrolepis spp., Schoenus spp., Bizula spp. etc. The soil is red clay to clay loam and the ironstone outcropping is often massive. This community also contains a number of endemic and restricted flora, such as Darwinia ferricola (Endangered), Grevillea manglesioides subsp. ferricola (Priority 2), Lambertia orbifolia subsp. Scott River Plains (Endangered) and Melaleuca incana subsp. Gingilup (Priority 2).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Microbial tufa community (Black Point Type)
Microbial tufa community (Black Point Type)
Microbial tufa community (Black Point Type)
Aquatic Root Mat Community Number 1 of Caves of the Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: At Yanchep and on the Leeuwin Naturaliste Ridge, permanent streams and pools occur in caves and some support dense growths of root mats. The root mats provide a constant and abundant primary food source for some of the richest aquatic cave communities known. The communities comprise a complete food web; the rootlets and their associated microflora providing the primary food source, and invertebrate assemblages including root mat grazers, predators, parasites, detritivores and scavengers, completing the trophic interactions. The roots from living Tuart trees branch out forming root mats in permanent cave streams. The aquatic rootlets contain extensive growths of microscopic fungi within their tissues which probably increase the nutritional value of the mats (Jasinska, 1995). The root mats house more than 50 percent of the animals that occur in any one cave stream at Yanchep (Jasinska, 1995). The remainder occur in open water, root detritus, and among the sand interstices of the stream bed (Jasinska, 1995).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Stromatolite like freshwater microbialite community of coastal brackish lakes
EC_DESC: Thrombolite community formed by biologically influenced precipitation of aragonite in a coastal brackish lake (Lake Clifton). The community occurs on a relict foredune plain on Holocene sands at Lake Clifton, southwest of Mandurah and is a complex association of photosynthetic cyanobacteria and purple sulphur bacteria, eukaryotic microalgae and what are known as ‘true bacteria’. Thrombolitic structures (those that have an internal clotted structure as opposed to those that have a laminated organisation which are stromatolitic) are formed through precipitation of calcium carbonate within the microenvironment of microbes as a result of photosynthetic and metabolic activity. The major process in the formation of the thrombolites is the precipitation of aragonite in a microenvironment determined by bacteria Scytonema sp. and other members of the BMC such as microalgae, in a process of biologically-influenced mineralization (Moore and Burne, 1994). The filamentous cyanobacteria Scytonema seculum is a dominant and oher cyanobacteria in the BMC include Oscillatoria, Dichothrix, Choococcus, Gleocapsa, Johannesbaptista, Gomphosphaeria and Spirulina. The eukaryotes include suite is composed of diatoms and macroalgae. The diatoms can live together with the BMC or as phytoplankton and the macroalgae has epiphytic or periphytic habits (Burne and Moore, 1994).

EC_DESC: Thrombolite community formed by biologically influenced precipitation of aragonite in a coastal brackish lake (Lake Clifton). The community occurs on a relict foredune plain on Holocene sands at Lake Clifton, southwest of Mandurah and is a complex association of photosynthetic cyanobacteria and purple sulphur bacteria, eukaryotic microalgae and what are known as ‘true bacteria’. Thrombolitic structures (those that have an internal clotted structure as opposed to those that have a laminated organisation which are stromatolitic) are formed through precipitation of calcium carbonate within the microenvironment of microbes as a result of photosynthetic and metabolic activity. The major process in the formation of the thrombolites is the precipitation of aragonite in a microenvironment determined by bacteria Scytonema sp. and other members of the BMC such as microalgae, in a process of biologically-influenced mineralization (Moore and Burne, 1994). The filamentous cyanobacteria Scytonema seculum is a dominant and oher cyanobacteria in the BMC include Oscillatoria, Dichothrix, Choococcus, Gleocapsa, Johannesbaptista, Gomphosphaeria and Spirulina. The eukaryotes include suite is composed of diatoms and macroalgae. The diatoms can live together with the BMC or as phytoplankton and the macroalgae has epiphytic or periphytic habits (Burne and Moore, 1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Communities of Tumulus Springs (Organic Mound Springs, Swan Coastal Plain)
EC_DESC:
The habitat of this community is characterised by continuous discharge of groundwater in raised areas of peat. The peat and surrounds provide a stable, permanently moist series of microhabitats. The springs are associated with a high level of heterogeneity of invertebrate fauna assemblages. Groups commonly represented to date include Ostracoda, Nematoda, Cladocera, Copepoda, Oligochaeta, Tardigrada, Turbellaria and Insecta.

Typical and common native vascular plant species associated with the tumulus springs are the trees Banksia littoralis, Melaleuca preissiana and Eucalyptus rudis, and the shrubs Agonis linearifolia, Pteridium esculentum, Astartea fascicularis and Cyclosorus interruptus. The following non-vascular plants have also been located on peat mounds associated with the community: Lycopodium serpentium (bog clubmoss), Riccardia aequicellularis, Jungermannia inundata, Goebelobryum unguiculatum and Hyalolepidozia longiscypha.

Common weed species include Isolepis prolifera and Pennisetum clandestinum.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Communities of Tumulus Springs (Organic Mound Springs, Swan Coastal Plain)
Communities of Tumulus Springs (Organic Mound Springs, Swan Coastal Plain)
Communities of Tumulus Springs (Organic Mound Springs, Swan Coastal Plain)
Stromatolite like microbialite community of coastal freshwater lakes
EC_DESC: This community occurs on the relic foredune plain on Holocene sands at Lake Richmond, Rockingham and is a complex association of photosynthetic cyanobacteria and purple sulphur bacteria, eukaryotic microalgae and ‘true bacteria’. Thrombolitic structures (those that have an internal clotted structure as opposed to those that have a laminated organisation which are stromatolitic) are formed through precipitation of calcium carbonate within the microenvironment of microbes as a result of photosynthetic and metabolic activity. These microbes are likely to include cyanobacteria dominated by Dichothrix sp., and other photosynthetic bacteria that depend on light for growth and survival. The source of the calcium in the waters of Lake Richmond is probably groundwater that has passed through sand dunes that surround the lake. The sands are calcareous and composed of quartz sands and shell debris of Aeolian origin (deposited by the wind). Thrombolite assemblage dominated by ?Dicothrix in coastal lake with TDS 791.9, alkalinity 237, pH 8.95 as at 5/4/2011

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Herb rich saline shrublands in clay pans
EC_DESC: This community is generally dominated by Melaleuca viminea, M. uncinata, M. cuticularis or Casuarina obesa or a mixture of these species. This community occurs on heavy clay soils that are generally inundated from winter into mid summer. The species composition (Melaleuca cuticularis and Casuarina obesa) may indicate some saline influence for at least some part of the year. Common herbs such as Brachyscome bellidioides, Centrolepis polygyna, Pogonolepis stricta and Cotula coronopifolia are typical of this community. In addition species such as Angianthus drummondii, Eryngium pinnatifidum subsp. palustre, and Blennospora drummondii occur in this community in low frequency. A suite of annual flora is seen in this community type as the season progresses. In early spring many of the occurrences of this threatened community are covered by free water up to 30 cm deep. Cotula coronopifolia sometimes forms yellow floating mats in some pools while others may be dominated by Villarsia submersa. Aquatic species are common in this community type early in the growing season. As the wetland dries a succession of species such as Centrolepis spp. and annual Stylidium spp. successively germinate, grow and flower, resulting in an extended flowering period of over three months. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 7’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Herb rich saline shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich saline shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
EC_DESC: This community occurs in low lying flats with a clay impending layer allowing seasonal inundation. The vegetation can be dominated by Viminaria juncea, Melaleuca viminea, M. lateritia or M. uncinata but also occasionally by Eucalyptus wandoo. The occurrence of species such as Hypocalymma angustifolium, Acacia lasiocarpa var. bracteolata (long peduncle form) and Verticordia huegelii at moderate frequencies, and aquatic annuals is common. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 8’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
EC_DESC: This community occurs in low lying flats with a clay impending layer allowing seasonal inundation. The vegetation can be dominated by Viminaria juncea, Melaleuca viminea, M. lateritia or M. uncinata but also occasionally by Eucalyptus wandoo. The occurrence of species such as Hypocalymma angustifolium, Acacia lasiocarpa var. bracteolata (long peduncle form) and Verticordia huegelii at moderate frequencies, and aquatic annuals is common. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 8’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
Herb rich shrublands in clay pans
Dense shrublands on clay flats
EC_DESC: This community occurs as shrublands or open woodlands on clay flats that are inundated for long periods. Sedges are more apparent in this community than in other claypans, with moderate frequencies of Chorizandra enodis, Cyathocaeta avenacea, Lepidosperma longitudinale and Leptocarpus coangustatus. This community has a lower species richness and weed frequency than other threatened claypan communities. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 9’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Dense shrublands on clay flats
Dense shrublands on clay flats
Shrublands on dry clay flats
EC_DESC: This community occurs on clay flats with thin skeletal soils and includes aquatic annuals and geophytes such as Schoenus natans, Eryngium pinnatifidum subsp. palustre ms, Wurmbea dioica subsp. alba and Amphibromus neesii which are also typical of other clay pan and clay flat communities. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 10a’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994). The type is one of the most rapidly drying of the group of clay flat communities identified in the 1994 report.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Shrublands on dry clay flats
Shrublands on dry clay flats
Banksia attenuata woodland over species rich dense shrublands
EC_DESC: This community occurs on sands at the base of the Darling Scarp in the Forrestfield area and north of Perth in the Koondoola and Chittering areas. This community is very species rich and is usually dominated by Banksia attenuata (occasionally with Eucalyptus marginata) with Bossiaea eriocarpa, Conostephium pendulum, Hibbertia huegelii, H. hypericoides, Petrophile linearis, Scaevola repens, Stirlingia latifolia, Mesomelaena pseudostygia and Alexgeorgea nitens being common in the understory. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 20a’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Banksia attenuata woodland over species rich dense shrublands
Banksia attenuata woodland over species rich dense shrublands
EC_DESC: This community occurs on sands at the base of the Darling Scarp in the Forrestfield area and north of Perth in the Koondoola and Chittering areas. This community is very species rich and is usually dominated by Banksia attenuata (occasionally with Eucalyptus marginata) with Bossiaea eriocarpa, Conostephium pendulum, Hibbertia huegelii, H. hypericoides, Petrophile linearis, Scaevola repens, Stirlingia latifolia, Mesomelaena pseudostygia and Alexgeorgea nitens being common in the understory. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 20a’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Banksia attenuata and/or Eucalyptus marginata woodlands of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: This species-rich community occurs on sands at the base of the Scarp between Byford and Yarloop. Most of the occurrences of this community type are Eucalyptus marginata – Banksia attenuata woodlands but the type also occurs as Banksia woodlands and heaths. A diverse shrub layer with Hakea stenocarpa, Conostylis setosa, and Johnsonia aff. pubescens being common components differentiates this community type. Mesomelaena pseudostygia occurs frequently in the community. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 20b’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Banksia attenuata and/or Eucalyptus marginata woodlands of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain
Banksia attenuata and/or Eucalyptus marginata woodlands of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain
Shrublands and woodlands of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: The community occurs mainly on the transitional soils of the Ridge Hill Shelf, on the Swan Coastal Plain adjacent to the Darling Scarp, but also extends marginally onto the alluvial clays deposited on the eastern fringe of the Swan Coastal Plain. The community occurs as a shrubland, or a woodland of Banksia attenuata and Banksia menziesii, sometimes with Allocasuarina fraseriana, over a shrub layer that can include the species Adenanthos cygnorum, Hibbertia huegelii, Scaevola repens var. repens, Allocasuarina humilis, Bossiaea eriocarpa, Hibbertia hypericoides and Stirlingia latifolia. A suite of herbs including Conostylis aurea, Trachymene pilosa, Lomandra hermaphrodita, Burchardia umbellata and Patersonia occidentalis, and the sedges Mesomelaena pseudostygia and Lyginia barbata usually occur in the community. The weeds Gladiolus caryophyllaceus and Ursinia anthemoides are also common.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Callitris preissii (or Melaleuca lanceolata) forests and woodlands, Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: This community occurs on the Quindalup system and consists of Callitris preissii, Melaleuca lanceolata and (occasionally) Eucalyptus gomphocephala forests and woodlands. It is restricted to a small area from Perth to Garden Island. Typically this community has a dense overstorey with relatively few understorey taxa. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 30a’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

Eucalyptus calophylla - Kingia australis woodlands on heavy soils, Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: A woodland community located on heavy soils of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain between Capel and Hazelmere. Typical and common native taxa in the community are: Corymbia calophylla; the shrubs Banksia nivea, Philotheca spicata, Kingia australis and Xanthorrhoea preissii; herbs, rushes and sedges, Cyathochaeta avenacea, Dampiera linearis, Haemodorum laxum, Desmocladus fasciculatus, Mesomelaena tetragona and Tetraria octandra. The introduced grass Briza maxima is also common in the community.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Eucalyptus calophylla - Eucalyptus marginata woodlands on sandy clay soils of the southern Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: Most sites of this community type are dominated by both Corymbia calophylla and Eucalyptus marginata, with Bossiaea eriocarpa and Conostylis juncea typical of this particular community. Many of the occurrences are found on the alluvial soils better-drained sites on the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 3b’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

The community is named ‘Eucalyptus calophylla—Xanthorrhoea preissii woodlands and shrublands’, but is sometimes called Swan Coastal Plain Community type 3c. This community can also include the occasional wandoo (Eucalyptus wandoo), and usually contains prickly moses (Acacia pulchella), couch honeypot, margin leaf pea (Gompholobium marginatum), white myrtle (Hypocalymma angustifolia) and herbs.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Unwooded freshwater wetlands of the southern Wheatbelt dominated by Muehlenbeckia horrida subsp. abdita and Tecticornia verrucosa
EC_DESC: Unwooded freshwater wetlands of the southern Wheatbelt of Western Australia, dominated by Muehlenbeckia horrida subsp. abdita and Tecticornia verrucosa across the lake floor. This shrub-dominated community is characterised by intermittent fresh water inundation and sometimes holds little water for several consecutive years. The major components of the community and other biota depend on relatively fresh water and regular drying out of the clay and silt wetland bed for survival.  In addition to the species referred to in the title, the wetlands support fringing open woodlands of Eucalyptus occidentalis over Melaleuca strobophylla dominated scrub.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Assemblages of the organic springs and mound springs of Mandora Marsh area
EC_DESC:
Assemblages of flora and fauna associated with the organic spring and mound spring wetland ecosystems of Mandora Marsh area in the southern Dampierland and Great Sandy Desert Bioregions, 200 km south of Broome.  These wetland ecosystems comprise spring-fed swamps with peaty substrates, many of which form raised peat mounds over the source of the spring. The wetlands vary in size from 0.1 ha to several hectares.  Water samples analysed from several mound springs ranged from fresh to brackish; brackish springs tend to be closer to the main lake and therefore lower in the landscape (Storey et al. in prep.). Approximately 15 million years ago the Mandora Marsh area was part of a large drainage system called the Wallal Paleoriver.  The distribution of mound springs appears linked to calcrete development along the paleodrainage line.  While unconfirmed, it has been suggested that the springs have developed where disruption of the calcrete layer has occurred allowing groundwater to come to the surface (Graham 1999). 
Plant assemblages associated with these ecosystems include paperbark Melaleuca leucadendra or M. cajuputi forest with or without an understorey of mangrove ferns Acrostichum speciosum, and/or  dragon tree Sesbania formosa woodland with or without an understorey of mangrove ferns.  Also present are stands of the bullrush Typha domingensis and sedgelands dominated by Schoenoplectus spp. with Fimbristylis spp., along with patches of the grass Sporobolus virginicus.  In addition, a few mangroves Avicennia marina occur on the more brackish springs.  Some Acacia ampliceps is often present in the mid-storey but is not abundant.  Typha domingensis and sedges with a few emergent trees or mangroves dominate the vegetation on some of the small mound springs.  Not only is the dominant vegetation of the various springs variable between occurrences, it is variable over time as the area is frequently subject to cyclonic winds that physically damage the vegetation.  In particular, cyclones knock down the tree canopy permitting the mangrove fern understorey to dominate until the tree canopy recovers.
The aquatic invertebrate fauna of the springs is relatively depauperate in comparison with other studies. The Insecta are characterised by species with strong-flying adult stages, promoting efficient dispersion, and as such, the macroinvertebrates contained few taxa with limited distributions or endemicity to the area. The majority of endemic taxa were recorded from the microinvertbrate fauna, but diversity and levels of endemism were relatively low compared to other detailed fauna surveys.  However, Assiminea sp. nov is new to science and is endemic to these springs and two of the Mandora rotifers are new (a Brachionus related to the cosmotropical B. budapestinensis, and a Cephalodella close to the South American C. boettgeri.).  While the cladoceran (Branchiopoda: Anomopoda/Ctenopoda) representation in the microfauna is depauperate relative to other W.A. studies and Australia in general, with only five taxa identified from the Mandora series.  However, four of the five taxa collected are probably endemic, although regional distribution on a continental basis is not known (Storey et al. in prep.).  Further results of invertebrate fauna identification are pending.
Preliminary comparisons of invertebrate fauna from mound springs of the Mandora Marsh area with other mound springs further north in the Kimberley Region, show that the fauna of the Kimberley mound springs is substantially richer, and that very few species are common to both areas. Some components of the Kimberley mound spring fauna (eg. Ostracods and Copepods) have a strong Asian element, and in general these springs support a distinctive high-rainfall Kimberley fauna, while the Mandora Marsh mound springs host fauna more typical of the arid Pilbara region (S. Halse pers. comm).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Assemblages of the organic springs and mound springs of Mandora Marsh area
Assemblages of the organic springs and mound springs of Mandora Marsh area
Assemblages of Dragon Tree Soak organic mound spring
EC_DESC: Dragon Tree Soak is an organic mound spring which comprises a permanent swamp and soak of black peaty mud, surrounded by an irregular dampland of grey loam flat and claypan.  At its centre, this wetland supports a closed sedgeland of jointed twig-rush Baumea articulata, at 2.5 m high and 95% canopy cover. The dragon tree Sesbania formosa occurs as a sparse emergent and some clumps of the bullrush Typha domingensis are also present in the centre of the soak. At the southern and northern ends of the swamp is a low-closed forest/scrub of Sesbania formosa, averaging 10 m in height, with some Typha domingensis understorey. In wet areas on the periphery of the swamp, a grassland of Paspalum vaginatum (couch grass) occurs, with sparse emergent Fimbristylis ferruginea. The slightly higher and drier surrounding flats support Sporobolus virginicus, Acacia ampliceps and Melaleuca glomerata.  The priority (P3) sedge species Fimbristylis sieberiana also occurs at Dragon Tree Soak.  Dragon Tree Soak is an example of an oasis within a major desert. It is a rare wetland landform, and a rare ecosystem, supporting plants and animals that are absent or scarce elsewhere in the bioregion. Due to its peaty sediments, Dragon Tree Soak is an important research site for studies of paleo-climate in north-western Australia. Carbon datings and pollen records from core samples indicate continued uninterrupted deposition of peat at the site for at least the last 6000 years, pointing to general climatic stability.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Assemblages of Bunda Bunda organic mound springs
EC_DESC: Organic mound spring communities of Bunda Bunda, Dampierland Bioregion.  The site consists of an area of two organic mound springs on tidal mudflats in Carnot Bay on Dampier Peninsula north of Broome. These springs are approximately 200 m apart and about 300 m from the shore.  The peaty mounds rise c. 2-3 m above the surrounding tidal flats and are composed of accumulated leaf litter and living vegetation, supporting a dense rainforest (closed forest) and a tall shrubland respectively, each with mangroves in concentriform arrangement. The smaller mound is dry in the centre, but encircled by a moat, fed by permanent freshwater seepage. The larger mound is wet and incompletely ringed by a leptoscale channel or moat of variable depth which broadens to a microscale saline lake (300 m long, 50 m wide) on the north side. The moats and lake are saline and occasionally inundated during large tides.  The western end of the larger mound is covered by a very dense (closed) forest dominated by evergreen Carallia brachiata trees to 20 m and a bracken-like layer of the fern Cyclosorus interruptus (to 1 m). This is the most southerly population of Carallia in Western Australia. A few Timonius timon and dragon trees Sesbania formosa occur. The east end of the island is slightly lower, more moist and the leaf litter forms a 'spongier' substrate. It is covered by tall closed forest (to 20 m) of Melaleuca cajuputi, T. timon, S. formosa with fewer C. brachiata and an understorey of C. interruptus. Creepers including Cassytha filiformis and the broadleaved Secamone elliptic, drape from trees, and climbing Maidenhair Ferns Lygodium microphyllum form a curtain which filters the light.  In the moat-like channel surrounding the large mound are mangroves and the mangrove fern Acrostichum speciosum, with an occurrence of the uncommon mangrove Lumnitzera racemosa on the eastern side. An endemic (Kimberley) mistletoe, Amyema dolichopodum also occurs on the site. The two mounds differ from each other and there is considerable spatial variation in vegetation within each site. There is a clear zonation in the vegetation around the smaller south-western mound spring. It is fringed by a ring of mangroves, predominantly Rhizophora stylosa and Avicennia marina. Within this lies a band of mangrove fern Acrostichum speciosum and trees of cadjeput Melaleuca cajuputi and Timonius timon to 12 m. In the dry centre of the island is a tall shrubland dominated by Acacia neurocarpa to 5 m, over grasses and sedges. The mudflats around the two mounds are bare of vegetation, but a Sporobolus grassland grows closer to the shore.  One of the most southerly occurrences of rainforest in Western Australia. The rainforest species of this community are common to rainforest patches across northern Australia (many of which have much greater species diversity), but are unusual in such a seasonally arid environment.  The site provides an isolated refuge for rainforest and riparian plant species, as well as a cool microclimate and freshwater for birds and other fauna.  Carallia brachiata produces a large crop of red berries around October, which is a food source for several species of bird including the Channel-billed Cuckoo Scythrops novaehollandiae and Pheasant Coucal Centropus phasianinus.  Other birds feed on flowering mangroves.

Species-rich faunal community of the intertidal mudflats of Roebuck Bay
EC_DESC: Roebuck Bay is a sheltered marine embayment with relatively little fresh water input and slower tidal flows, with large flats composed of sediments of carbonate origin exposed at low tide. It supports a diverse and abundant marine fauna, including distinct assemblages of benthic invertebrates, and a high diversity and high abundance of transequatorial migratory shorebirds. It is a Wetland of International importance and is recognised as one of the most important sites in the world for migratory waders.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Species-rich faunal community of the intertidal mudflats of Roebuck Bay
EC_DESC: Roebuck Bay is a sheltered marine embayment with relatively little fresh water input and slower tidal flows, with large flats composed of sediments of carbonate origin exposed at low tide. It supports a diverse and abundant marine fauna, including distinct assemblages of benthic invertebrates, and a high diversity and high abundance of transequatorial migratory shorebirds. It is a Wetland of International importance and is recognised as one of the most important sites in the world for migratory waders.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Vine thickets on coastal sand dunes of Dampier Peninsula
EC_DESC: Semi-deciduous vine thicket communities on leeward slopes of coastal sand dunes on Dampier Peninsula.  Occur as discontinuous but discrete pockets of dense vegetation, ranging from a few trees to around 60 ha in size.  Patches tend to be larger with Worsening condition dune system size, and are generally better developed in structure and higher in species diversity at the northern end of the peninsula.  The principal upper-storey tree species include: Cassine melanocarpa, Celtis philippinensis, Diospyros ferrea var. humilis, Ficus virens, Melaleuca cajuputi, M. dealbata, M. viridiflora, Mimusops elengi, Pouteria sericea, and Terminalia petiolaris.  The understorey comprises shrub species such as: Croton tomentellus, Dodonaea platyptera, Exocarpos latifolius, Pandanus spiralis, Plumbago zeylanica, Santalum lanceolatum, and Securinega melanthesoides.  Vine species include: Abrus precatorius, Adenia heterophylla, Caesalpinia globulorum, Gymnanthera nitida, Jacquemontia paniculata, Marsdenia cinerascens, Passiflora foetida and Tinospora smilacina.  Soils are deep dune sands, white except for a superficial dark grey organic layer, and covered by leaf litter up to 6 cm in depth (Beard and Kenneally 1993).

Organic mound spring sedgeland community of the North Kimberley Bioregion
EC_DESC: Organic mound spring sedgeland community of the North Kimberley Bioregion. Sedgelands with sparse emergent Melaleuca sp., Pandanus spiralis or Banksia dentata. These organic mound springs support sedgelands with sparse emergent Melaleuca nervosa, Pandanus spiralis, and/or Banksia dentata. Among the diverse and abundant sedges and herbs is Eriocaulon inapertum which was previously known as endemic to the top end of the Northern Territory. Other mound springs surveyed in the Kimberley Region are vegetated by forest/woodland.  Most of the sedges present on these mound springs are restricted to the periphery of wetlands and creeks, or broad drainage depressions on sandier soils where grasses are dominant. This wetland is considered worthy of conservation based on the particular aquatic invertebrate fauna present, and their importance. This particular type of mound springs is only known from four Pastoral Stations in the North Kimberley Bioregion (Halse, 2001).

EC_DESC: Organic mound spring sedgeland community of the North Kimberley Bioregion. Sedgelands with sparse emergent Melaleuca sp., Pandanus spiralis or Banksia dentata. These organic mound springs support sedgelands with sparse emergent Melaleuca nervosa, Pandanus spiralis, and/or Banksia dentata. Among the diverse and abundant sedges and herbs is Eriocaulon inapertum which was previously known as endemic to the top end of the Northern Territory. Other mound springs surveyed in the Kimberley Region are vegetated by forest/woodland.  Most of the sedges present on these mound springs are restricted to the periphery of wetlands and creeks, or broad drainage depressions on sandier soils where grasses are dominant. This wetland is considered worthy of conservation based on the particular aquatic invertebrate fauna present, and their importance. This particular type of mound springs is only known from four Pastoral Stations in the North Kimberley Bioregion (Halse, 2001).

Black Spring organic mound spring community
EC_DESC: Organic mound spring community in the North Kimberley Bioregion. A raised central mound supports a forest of Melaleuca viridiflora, Ficus spp., Timonius timon, and Pandanus spiralis over taro lillies Colocasia esculenta and ferns Cyclosorus interruptus.  The very tall cane grass Phragmites karka dominates the outer edge of the mound and the entire mound is ringed by a moat of water supporting sedges and grasses.

Assemblages of Roe River rainforest swamp
EC_DESC:
Rainforest on a spring-fed swamp on a small alluvial floodplain behind a tidal mudflat at the mouth of a sandstone valley in the estuary of the Roe River, in the north-west Kimberley.  McKenzie et al. (1990) sampled 1 occurrence of this community, Patch 16/2.  It was described as occurring in the wettest part of the study area (1200 mm rainfall).
The lithology of the site is Quaternary alluvium and King Leopold Sandstone/Hart dolerite.  Soil drainage is excessive or free, and soil inundation is seasonal.  The subsurface soil is a very dark grey sand.  Leaf litter depth was recorded as 5 cm during the Kimberley Rainforest Survey.  The rainforest canopy is 16 m high.  The Kimberley Rainforest Survey recorded perennial plant species richness at 29, bird species richness at 24, and total community species richness at 67.  Tree species include: Algaia elaeagnoidea, Alphitonia excelsa, Alstonia actinophylla, Antidesma ghaesembilla, Bombax ceiba, Carallia brachiata, Cryptocarya cunninghamii, Ficus hispida, Lophostemon grandiflorus rip., Melaleuca viridiflora, Melastoma malabathricum, Memecylon pauciflorum, Nauclea orientalis, Polyalthia australis, Pouteria sericea, Syzygium angophoroides, Syzyygium forte potamophilum, Timonius timon, Trema tomentosa var. viridus, and Vitex acuminata.  Most of the camaenid land snails recorded in the Kimberley Rainforest Survey are restricted endemics in the Kimberley.  The median linear range for a wet area Kimberley camaenid is 20km, and 82 of the 93 camaenids were only collected in 1 to 5 patches.  Consequently, the rainforest communities of the Kimberley Region can be distinguished from similar rainforest communities elsewhere in northern Australia.

Assemblages of Theda Soak rainforest swamp
EC_DESC: Closed canopy rainforest on a freshwater soak (Theda Soak) on a floodplain in the north Kimberley. McKenzie et al. (1990) described this patch of rainforest as a small patch around a spring-fed soak on a floodplain.  It occurs 0.5 km from a tributary of the Morgan River.  Only one occurrence is recorded.  It is described as being a discrete patch of rainforest on a moderate slope. The lithology is Quaternary alluvium.  The subsurface soil is a very dark grey sandy loam.  Leaf litter depth of 10 cm was recorded during the Kimberley Rainforest Survey.  The height of the rainforest canopy is 20 m. The trees include: Albizia lebbeck, Antidesma ghaesembilla, Bombax ceiba, Garuga floribunda, Glochidion disparipes, Ficus opposita, Ficus racemosa var. racemosa, Litsea glutinosa, Melaleuca leucadendra, Sesbania formosa, Sterculia quadrifida, Syzygium nervosum, and Terminalia sericocarpa.  The Kimberley Rainforest Survey recorded a perennial plant species richness of 17, bird species richness at 12, and a total species richness of 36 (McKenzie et al. 1991).  Most of the camaenid land snails recorded in the Kimberley Rainforest Survey are restricted endemics in the Kimberley.  The median linear range for a wet area Kimberley camaenid is 20km, and 82 of the 93 camaenids were only collected in 1 to 5 patches (Solem 1991).  Consequently, the rainforest communities of the Kimberley Region can be distinguished from similar rainforest communities elsewhere in northern Australia.

(1990) described this patch of rainforest as a small patch around a spring-fed soak on a floodplain.  It occurs 0.5 km from a tributary of the Morgan River.  Only one occurrence is recorded.  It is described as being a discrete patch of rainforest on a moderate slope. The lithology is Quaternary alluvium.  The subsurface soil is a very dark grey sandy loam.  Leaf litter depth of 10 cm was recorded during the Kimberley Rainforest Survey.  The height of the rainforest canopy is 20 m. The trees include: Albizia lebbeck, Antidesma ghaesembilla, Bombax ceiba, Garuga floribunda, Glochidion disparipes, Ficus opposita, Ficus racemosa var. racemosa, Litsea glutinosa, Melaleuca leucadendra, Sesbania formosa, Sterculia quadrifida, Syzygium nervosum, and Terminalia sericocarpa.  The Kimberley Rainforest Survey recorded a perennial plant species richness of 17, bird species richness at 12, and a total species richness of 36 (McKenzie et al. 1991).  Most of the camaenid land snails recorded in the Kimberley Rainforest Survey are restricted endemics in the Kimberley.  The median linear range for a wet area Kimberley camaenid is 20km, and 82 of the 93 camaenids were only collected in 1 to 5 patches (Solem 1991).  Consequently, the rainforest communities of the Kimberley Region can be distinguished from similar rainforest communities elsewhere in northern Australia.

Assemblages of Walcott Inlet rainforest swamps
EC_DESC: Tall closed-canopied swamp rainforest on the extensive floodplain that fringes a tidal mudflat in the Walcott Inlet.  McKenzie et al. (1990) sampled the 3 known occurrences of this community type, which, being on swampy terrain adjacent to sandstone ridges, was described as markedly different from other patches of rainforest.  Stoneman et al. (1991) described Patch 19/2 in detail.  The swamp is fed by streams from sandstone hills and appears to be part of a broad watercourse.  Water drains from the swamp towards the tidal mud flats.  At the time of survey (June 1987) there was free water to at least 30 cm deep in the central part of the swamp.  Higher ground with a tall Melaleuca forest occurs in the centre of the swamp area.  The soils are generally highly organic and in places composed of layers with different textures.  The vegetation comprises closed-canopy rainforest to 30 m in height, and is dominated by Ficus spp., Nauclea orientalis, and Celtis philippinensis over 1-3 m high Acrostychum speciosum (ferns).  During the Kimberley Rainforest Survey, the two species Cordia subcordata (tree) and Torresitrachia sp. (snail), were recorded once only, at Patch 19/2 (McKenzie and Belbin 1991).  The lithology of the 3 occurrences is Quaternary alluvium.  The subsurface soil is a black silty clay at 18/4, a black sandy clay loam at 19/2, and a very dark grey sandy loam at 21/4.  Respectively, leaf litter depths of 7, 10, and 10 cm were recorded during the Kimberley Rainforest Survey (McKenzie et al. (1991).  At Patches 18/4, 19/2 and 21/4, the height of the rainforest canopy is 15, 27, and 20 m respectively.  The Kimberley Rainforest Survey recorded perennial plant species richness at 31, 96, and 33; bird species richness at 20, 36, and 15; and, total species richness of 59, 142, and 57.  Most of the camaenid land snails recorded in the Kimberley Rainforest Survey are restricted endemics in the Kimberley.  The median linear range for a wet area Kimberley camaenid is 20km, and 82 of the 93 camaenids were only collected in 1 to 5 patches.  Consequently, the rainforest communities of the Kimberley Region can be distinguished from similar rainforest communities elsewhere in northern Australia.

Assemblages of Big Springs organic mound springs
EC_DESC: Organic mound spring community of Big Springs, Dampierland.  A complex system of freshwater seepages and peaty springs with internal moats.  Situated on the eastern shore of King Sound, with broad tidal flats on the seaward margin and cracking clay flats on the landward margin. A further feature is the scattered clusters of small outlying, densely-vegetated mound springs. The main seepage area has an extensive outflow swamp on its north west side.  Within the complex, the substrate varies from peat through to peaty grey clay to grey clay.  The main seepage area supports well developed rainforest vegetation dominated by forests of Terminalia microcarpa, a species not otherwise known south of Walcott Inlet, 90 km to the north east.  Several mistletoe species (Loranthaceae) have been recorded in the Terminalia canopy, which reaches 20 m in places. Other trees present include cluster fig Ficus racemosa, banyan Ficus virens, the paperbark  Melaleuca ?leucadendra, Pandanus sp., dragon tree Sesbania formosa and Timonius timon.  Much less common species noted were Antidesma ghaesembilla, Diospyros maritima and Leichardt tree Nauclea orientalis. The understorey varies from central open glades with turf of Cyperaceae to pure leaf litter under the Terminalia canopies. Internal moats support the mangrove fern Acrostichum speciosum. Patches of duckweed Lemna aequinoctialis and, less commonly, hornwort Ceratophyllum demersum occur. One population of climbing swamp fern Stenochlaena palustris was noted. The outer perimeter of the large seepage feature is relatively dry in most places with this ring generally dominated by dense thickets of Melaleuca acacioides and/or Acacia ampliceps with scattered Bauhinia cunninghamii, chinese lantern Dichrostachys spicata and occasional boabs Adansonia gregorii of small stature. In the north west there is a perimeter swamp with extensive beds of narrowleaf cumbungi Typha domingensis and the sedge Schoenoplectus litoralis, with the occasional white-flowered black mangrove Lumnitzera racemosa. Outlying mound spring islands on tidal flats vary markedly in size and diversity of vegetation. Some of the smallest islands consist solely of Typha domingensis. Larger examples often feature Pandanus spiralis, Sesbania formosa, Acacia neurocarpa and occasionally Terminalia microcarpa and Ficus sp., with a range of Cyperaceae. Several islands were noted with unusual associations such as Typha growing with the mangrove Lumnitzera sp.

EC_DESC: The geology comprises a shale unit deposited during the Quaternary period.  This shale unit is in breakaways of ferruginised duricrust formed through exposure to mineralised ground water.  A white clay layer exists in some areas over the duricrust. The vegetation of this landform is described by Beard as Shrublands; mixed thicket of Melaleuca and Hakea and is restricted to the Port Gregory/Northampton region. The community appears to be restricted by the geology and only occurs where the Kockatea shale is exposed at the surface, and occurs on both the upper and lower slopes.breakaways of ferruginised duricrust formed through exposure to mineralised ground water.  A white clay layer exists in some areas over the duricrust. The vegetation of this landform is described by Beard as Shrublands; mixed thicket of Melaleuca and Hakea and is restricted to the Port Gregory/Northampton region. The community appears to be restricted by the geology and only occurs where the Kockatea shale is exposed at the surface, and occurs on both the upper and lower slopes.The vegetation of the lower slopes is often taller and denser than the rest of the community and is dominated by Melaleuca longistaminea, Melaleuca concreta and other Melaleuca species with occasional emergent Mallees. (Eucalyptus blaxellii, (VU) and another mallee)  The mid slope is dominated by Melaleuca longistaminea and in some areas Gastrolobium propinquum (P1) and Leucopogon sp Port Gregory are also frequent on the mid slopes.  In areas where there is little or no vegetation and highly exposed shale, Ptilotus helichrysoides is often present.Leucopogon sp Port Gregory and Ozothamnus sp Northampton are two new species that were discovered as part of recent survey work are only known from this community. A third new Dodonaea species may also occur here but is subject to further studies. This community also contains the only accurate locality for Ptilotus chortophytum (P1) for over 30 years.This community is unique in that it occurs on exposed Kockatea Shale.  Kockatea Shale occurs to the west of the scarp from Carnarvon to Bunbury, however it is rarely exposed.  The vegetation that occurs on the exposed Kockatea Shale Formation is defined by Beard as Hutt 675 and is restricted to the Northampton area. Therefore if Kockatea Shale was to be exposed at the surface in other areas it would be unlikely that the vegetation would be similar. (Mathew Cobb, Geologist, Pers Comm. December 2006)

Petrophile chrysantha low heath on Lesueur dissected uplands (Gp200-170)
Lesueur-Coomallo Floristic Community DFGH
EC_DESC: Mixed species-rich heath on lateritic gravel with Hakea erinacea, Melaleuca platycalyx and Petrophile seminuda: a fine scale mixture of four floristically-defined communities occurring on lateritic slopes. The four communities include 'D' Heath and woodlands on gravelly hills and slopes, 'F', 'G' and 'H' Heath on duplex soils, on benched slopes and broad valleys . Community 'D' comprises of five subtypes. D1: Allocasuarina microstachya Heath, D2: Hakea undulata Heath (Gravel type), D3: Leucopogon Heath, D4: Darwinia neildiana Heath and D5: Petrophile crysantha Heath. Community 'F' comprises of Hakea erinacea Heath, Community 'G' of Melaleuca platycalyx Heath and 'H' of Petrophile seminuda heath.

EC_DESC: Mixed species-rich heath on lateritic gravel with Hakea erinacea, Melaleuca platycalyx and Petrophile seminuda: a fine scale mixture of four floristically-defined communities occurring on lateritic slopes. The four communities include 'D' Heath and woodlands on gravelly hills and slopes, 'F', 'G' and 'H' Heath on duplex soils, on benched slopes and broad valleys . Community 'D' comprises of five subtypes. D1: Allocasuarina microstachya Heath, D2: Hakea undulata Heath (Gravel type), D3: Leucopogon Heath, D4: Darwinia neildiana Heath and D5: Petrophile crysantha Heath. Community 'F' comprises of Hakea erinacea Heath, Community 'G' of Melaleuca platycalyx Heath and 'H' of Petrophile seminuda heath.

Lesueur-Coomallo Floristic Community M2 (Melaleuca preissiana woodland)
Eucalypt woodlands of the Western Australian Wheatbelt
EC_DESC:
This community includes all eucalypt-dominated woodlands in the Western Australian Wheatbelt region as defined by the Avon Wheatbelt 1 and 2 and Western Mallee subregions within the Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation of Australia (IBRA 6.1, Commonwealth of Australia, 2005) with the specific exceptions of: 
 
• Woodlands and forests dominated or co-dominated by Jarrah (E. marginata) and Marri (Corymbia calophylla) where they occur without York Gum present 
• Woodlands dominated or co-dominated by E. wandoo where it occurs in jarrah forest (but is included for Wheatbelt)
• Non-woodland communities dominated by eucalypts, specifically those dominated by eucalypts with a mallee growth form. 

The Wheatbelt eucalypt woodlands include a diversity of sub-communities in which the eucalypt species occur in association with other species characteristic of this region, such that together these species constitute a distinct ecological sub-community.  Both mallee and woodland forms of the key eucalypt species occur in association with either shrub or other understorey.  However, this community specifically focuses on woodland eucalypt sub-communities.  Although mallee eucalypts may be present, they are included only where they occur in the understorey.   
 
The community is intentionally broad in the diversity of sub-communities included because of the rich diversity and complexity of such communities, occurring in a fine-scale mosaic influenced by climate, topography, soils and hydrology, as well as land use.  
 
Among these communities, those dominated by Salmon Gum (Eucalyptus salmonophloia), York Gum (Eucalyptus loxophleba), Red Morrel (Eucalyptus longicornis) and Gimlet (Eucalyptus salubris) capture the most heavily cleared and at risk of the wheatbelt eucalypt woodlands.  Other eucalypt woodlands have also been extensively cleared (e.g. Wandoo (Eucalyptus wandoo), Wheatbelt Wandoo (Eucalyptus capillosa) and Powderbark Wandoo (Eucalyptus accedens) or occur only in small isolated patches (e.g. Mallets such as Eucalyptus singularis, Salt Gum (Eucalyptus salicola) and Yate (Eucalyptus occidentalis).

Among these communities, those dominated by Salmon Gum (Eucalyptus salmonophloia), York Gum (Eucalyptus loxophleba), Red Morrel (Eucalyptus longicornis) and Gimlet (Eucalyptus salubris) capture the most heavily cleared and at risk of the wheatbelt eucalypt woodlands.  Other eucalypt woodlands have also been extensively cleared (e.g. Wandoo (Eucalyptus wandoo), Wheatbelt Wandoo (Eucalyptus capillosa) and Powderbark Wandoo (Eucalyptus accedens) or occur only in small isolated patches (e.g. Mallets such as Eucalyptus singularis, Salt Gum (Eucalyptus salicola) and Yate (Eucalyptus occidentalis).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Eucalypt woodlands of the Western Australian Wheatbelt
EC_DESC:
This community includes all eucalypt-dominated woodlands in the Western Australian Wheatbelt region as defined by the Avon Wheatbelt 1 and 2 and Western Mallee subregions within the Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation of Australia (IBRA 6.1, Commonwealth of Australia, 2005) with the specific exceptions of: 
 
• Woodlands and forests dominated or co-dominated by Jarrah (E. marginata) and Marri (Corymbia calophylla) where they occur without York Gum present 
• Woodlands dominated or co-dominated by E. wandoo where it occurs in jarrah forest (but is included for Wheatbelt)
• Non-woodland communities dominated by eucalypts, specifically those dominated by eucalypts with a mallee growth form. 

The Wheatbelt eucalypt woodlands include a diversity of sub-communities in which the eucalypt species occur in association with other species characteristic of this region, such that together these species constitute a distinct ecological sub-community.  Both mallee and woodland forms of the key eucalypt species occur in association with either shrub or other understorey.  However, this community specifically focuses on woodland eucalypt sub-communities.  Although mallee eucalypts may be present, they are included only where they occur in the understorey.   
 
The community is intentionally broad in the diversity of sub-communities included because of the rich diversity and complexity of such communities, occurring in a fine-scale mosaic influenced by climate, topography, soils and hydrology, as well as land use.  
 
Among these communities, those dominated by Salmon Gum (Eucalyptus salmonophloia), York Gum (Eucalyptus loxophleba), Red Morrel (Eucalyptus longicornis) and Gimlet (Eucalyptus salubris) capture the most heavily cleared and at risk of the wheatbelt eucalypt woodlands.  Other eucalypt woodlands have also been extensively cleared (e.g. Wandoo (Eucalyptus wandoo), Wheatbelt Wandoo (Eucalyptus capillosa) and Powderbark Wandoo (Eucalyptus accedens) or occur only in small isolated patches (e.g. Mallets such as Eucalyptus singularis, Salt Gum (Eucalyptus salicola) and Yate (Eucalyptus occidentalis).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Lake MacLeod invertebrate Assemblages
EC_DESC:
Saline aquatic community with strong marine affinities with particularly rich copepod elements - is effectively a well developed, very rich birrida community with strong marine and terrestrial components with especially rich hypactacoid community. Distinctive but lacks threats. Lake MacLeod received marine groundwater, which upwells 20km inland in sinkholes on the western side of the lake, as well as surface inflow via the Minilya River, smaller creeks and sheet flow from the Gascoyne River after very heavy rain. It has been shown to support very high numbers of waterbirds, especially migratory shorebirds as well as containing some of the few inland stands of mangroves in Western Australia. Lake MacLeod was open to the sea during the Last Interglacial, and is an example of a very large birrida. Lake MacLeod has an area of 150,000ha when fully flooded. (Halse et. al., 2000) Blue Holes area seems unique (Winston Kay pers. comm.) Invertebrates show it very clearly to be a community of its own (S. Halse pers. comm).                                                                                                                                    Lake MacLeod includes distinct “inner wetlands” (sinkholes, channels, lakes, marshes) in the west and “floodout marshes” at river mouths in the north-east as well as a lake bed that is frequently inundated. Several macroscale islands lie in the east and north of the lake bed. The lake is situated in the Carnarvon Basin, in calcareous marine deposits. It is a former sea embayment that was separated from the sea at the south by development of sand dunes. Water from the ocean passes underground 18km through coastal limestone and under hydrostatic pressure rises up in sinkholes in the central west part of the lake bed. Sinkholes are several metres deep however the rest of the lake fluctuates from 0 to 1.5m deep. The lake is one of the most important non-tidal stop-over sites in Australia for migratory shorebirds. It also supports Australia’s largest inland community of mangroves and associated fauna. Plant structural formations include Low closed-forest to open-scrub/shrubland (mangroves). The mangrove community is the largest of only two inland occurrences in WA; the other is at Mandora Salt Marshes. The highest number of waterbirds counted was 114 956 in September 1987. A fish known as Amniataba caudavittatus – Yellow Trumpeter is known to occur in the sinkholes. The lake supports a major commercial saltfield; brine is obtained from the lake bed. Lake MacLeod (vacant crown land) is covered by a mining lease (Dampier Salt Co.) The site is included on the Register of the National Estate.

Taken from ‘A Directory of Important Wetlands in Australia (2nd Edition)

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Granite outcrop pools with endemic aquatic fauna
EC_DESC: Freshwater pools formed on granite outcrops that may persist for several months and house a variety of aquatic invertebrates, some of which are endemic to south-west WA. Some examples include cladocerans, ostracods, copepods, rotifers, oligochaetes and molluscs.

EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: there are thousands of occurences not currently mapped; current data points are the small number of granite outcrops sampled for wheatbelt survey but PEC is much larger. S&C: 680
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: general condition for extensive land use zone & forested zones, granites tend to be in good condition. Threats if they exist tend to be from physical disturbance.
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: similar for as for abiotic, these impacts change to assemblage over time
EC_LISTINGREASON: P2 - generally ? 10 occurrences or AOO ? 200 ha, some occurrences not under immediate threat

EC_NOTES1: Adrian Pinder: Differences in community composition over rainfall gradient (Brian Timms work). Interesting and endemic fauna isolated from surrounding low land. Gnerally high in landscape and historically not cleared so not subject to landscape level threats such as salinity, however assemblages may be changing due to climate change (long term reduced rainfall). AP not aware of monitoring over time to document examples of changes but pools persist in semi-arid areas so likely that endemic fauna will persist. Less threatened that other community types.

EC_KNOWNOCC_NOTES: S&C: 2 Dingo Rock, Dunn Rock. Other occurrences not mapped. Adrian Pinder: this list is the small number of granite outcrops sampled for wheatbelt survey, there are thousands of occurrences.
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: Unknown
EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: there are thousands of occurences not currently mapped; current data points are the small number of granite outcrops sampled for wheatbelt survey but PEC is much larger. S&C: 167
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: general condition for wheatbelt granite outctrops (ie. not only mapped occurrences), some impacts from physical disturbance grazing (sedimentation of pools and decrease in water quality)
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: similar for as for abiotic, these impacts change to assemblage over time
EC_LISTINGREASON: P2 - generally ? 10 occurrences or AOO ? 200 ha, some occurrences not under immediate threat
EC_TENURE: Other crown reserves, Freehold land, Other public lands - roads and water bodies, DEC managed land - reserves IUCN I-IV
EC_NOTES1: JM: refer to State level for notes
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: SC i.a) Taxonomic work to describe patterning/variability to assist alpha taxonomy or description of community community
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: classification of rocks based on assemblages to better define ecological communities
EC_MANREQ_EVALUATION: EV iv) Develop/implement monitoring and evaluation and reporting plan
EC_MANREQ_CONSPLAN_CAT: CP viii) Reserve area plan (DPaW tenure only; specify)
EC_MANREQ_CONSPLAN_SPECIFY: incorporate into reserve management where appropriate
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_CAT: MD iv) Herbivore/omnivore control or eradication
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_SPECIFY: rabbit control where appropriate, stock exclusion where appropriate
EC_MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI iii) Habitat management through informal or complementary conservation mechanisms (specify)
EC_MANREQ_INDIRECT_SPECIFY: liaison with land holder and other relevant stakeholders
EC_MANREQ_OTHER_SPECIFY: promotions values, how to use rocks without impacts
EC_NOTES2: Adrian Pinder: general management actions included, site dependant info required but can't be done until assemblages are described and occurrences are mapped.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Granite outcrop pools with endemic aquatic fauna
EC_PASTPRESSURES_SPECIFY: trampling & motor bike access can damage rock communities and cause sedimentation of pools
EC_FUTURETHREATS_SPECIFY: trampling & motor bike access can damage rock communities and cause sedimentation of pools
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: IN ii) Large-scale systematic biodiversity inventory (specify scale)
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: biological survey of granite outcrop aquatic fauna is required to determine variation in assemblage composition across the gradients.
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_CAT: MD xii) Manage access
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_SPECIFY: manage access to reduce trampling, damage to rock pool communities and runnoff of sediments and nutrients where appropriate
EC_MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI xii) Planning processes
EC_NOTES2: Adrian Pinder: this ecological community will likely be split into many assemblages on analisis of species composition but significant survey effort is required across geographical range.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Granite outcrop pools with endemic aquatic fauna
EC_DESC: Freshwater pools formed on granite outcrops that may persist for several months and house a variety of aquatic invertebrates, some of which are endemic to south-west WA. Some examples include cladocerans, ostracods, copepods, rotifers, oligochaetes and molluscs.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Granite outcrop pools with endemic aquatic fauna
EC_DESC: Freshwater pools formed on granite outcrops that may persist for several months and house a variety of aquatic invertebrates, some of which are endemic to south-west WA. Some examples include cladocerans, ostracods, copepods, rotifers, oligochaetes and molluscs.
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Unknown
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: Unknown
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: general condition for extensive land use zone, granites tend to be in good condition. Threats if they exist tend to be from physical disturbance.
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Adrian Pinder: similar for as for abiotic, these impacts change to assemblage over time
EC_LISTINGREASON: P2 - generally ? 10 occurrences or AOO ? 200 ha, some occurrences not under immediate threat
EC_NOTES1: JM: refer to State level for notes

EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: classification of rocks based on assemblages to better define ecological communities

EC_MANREQ_CONSPLAN_SPECIFY: incorporate into reserve management where appropriate
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_CAT: MD iv) Herbivore/omnivore control or eradication
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_SPECIFY: rabbit control where appropriate, stock exclusion where appropriate

EC_MANREQ_INDIRECT_SPECIFY: liaison with land holder and other relevant stakeholders
EC_MANREQ_OTHER_SPECIFY: promotions values, how to use rocks without impacts

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Fairy Shrimp communities of rock outcrops
EC_DESC: Invertebrate communities are unusual, some species known from relatively few outcrops but not under imminent threat. Mining could be an issue with regards to dust accumulation as it could affect pool chemistry, and especially with regard to flatter rocks at landscape level.
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Unknown
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: Unknown
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: JM: occurrences not mapped. Adrian Pinder: not a valid community type
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: JM: occurrences not mapped. Adrian Pinder: not a valid community type
EC_NOTES1: Adrian Pinder: Needs review, one species of fairy shrimp per rock pool, not an assemblage, community maybe not valid. Suggest expansion of Granite outcrop pools with endemic aquatic fauna PEC to other subregions.
EC_CHANGECONSSTATUS: Current PEC, likely removal from Priority list (NOT of conservation significance)
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: SC iii) Determination/re-evaluation of conservation status/formal classification
EC_NOTES2: Adrian Pinder: reassess conservation significance wrt definiting of community, if any rock outcrops are listed they should be as Granite outcrop pools with endemic aquatic fauna PEC.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Plant assemblages of the Moresby Range system
EC_DESC: Vegetation communities of the Moresby Range as mapped by Beard (1976).  Includes Melaleuca megacephala and Hakea pycnoneura thicket on stony slopes, Verticordia dominated low heath, and Allocasuarina campestris and Melaleuca uncinata thicket on superficial laterite, that cover the slopes, shallow soils of the ridges and summit of the range.
EC_KNOWNOCC_CAT: Less than or equal to 10 (potentially meets location criteria VU)
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Increase in occurrences (new knowledge - biological survey/mapping)
EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: mapped within last 10 years
EC_EOOAREA_CAT: < 10,000ha (potentially meets extent of occurrence criteria for CR)
EC_EOOAREA_METHOD: Minimum convex polygon of records in DPaW corporate database
EC_EOOAREA_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: mapped within last 10 years
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: < 10,000ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for CR)
EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: loss of veg community from southern most extent of range but before last 10 years, ongoing threats and degradation last 10 years, community defined within the last 10 years.
EC_DEGABIOTIC_RELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: poor condition areas were not mapped. Some natural regrowth, attempts at rehab but not considered successful, some small losses from fire breaks
EC_DEGBIOTIC_RELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: poor condition areas were not mapped. Some natural regrowth, attempts at rehab but not considered successful, some small losses from fire breaks

EC_TENURE: DEC managed land - reserves IUCN I-IV, Unallocated crown land, Freehold land, Other public lands - roads and water bodies
EC_NOTES1: Notes from workshop: Reserve areas haven't been farmed. Current and intensive grazing & burning, clearing for roads, gravel extractions. Include all ferals, fire & weeds. Potentially also illegal activities re: access to private land for hunting, dogs & hunters in conservation tenure

EC_FUTURETHREATS_SPECIFY: historic clearing and fragmentation of habitat

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Plant assemblages of the Moresby Range system
Coastal sands dominated by Acacia rostellifera, Eucalyptus oraria and Eucalyptus obtusiflora/Limestone Eucalyptus oraria, Eucalyptus obtusiflora (mallee)
EC_COMMUNITYID: Coastal sands dominated by Acacia rostellifera, Eucalyptus oraria and Eucalyptus obtusiflora.
EC_DESC:
Floristically, this community is similar to other Acacia rostellifera communities but is differentiated on
structure, being dominated by mallee eucalypts. The community occurs on limestone ridges, in some swales
in the coastal dunes between Cape Burney and Dongara, on the Greenough Alluvial Flats on limestone soil
and near Tarcoola Beach. Some very small occurrences have also been recorded on the limestone scarp north
of the Buller River.
EC_KNOWNOCC_CAT: Less than or equal to 20 (does not meet IUCN location criteria)
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Increase in occurrences (new knowledge - biological survey/mapping)
EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_EOOAREA_NOTES: not available in nomination form, no spatial info
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: < 100ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for CR)

EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: nomination form July 2012 - decline in condition over last 10 years

EC_TENURE: Freehold land
EC_NOTES1: Limestone Eucalyptus oraria, Eucalyptus obtusiflora (mallee) nomination name. EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Coastal sands dominated by Acacia rostellifera, Eucalyptus oraria and Eucalyptus obtusiflora/Limestone Eucalyptus oraria, Eucalyptus obtusiflora (mallee)
EC_COMMUNITYID: Coastal sands dominated by Acacia rostellifera, Eucalyptus oraria and Eucalyptus obtusiflora.
EC_DESC:
Floristically, this community is similar to other Acacia rostellifera communities but is differentiated on
structure, being dominated by mallee eucalypts. The community occurs on limestone ridges, in some swales
in the coastal dunes between Cape Burney and Dongara, on the Greenough Alluvial Flats on limestone soil
and near Tarcoola Beach. Some very small occurrences have also been recorded on the limestone scarp north
of the Buller River.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Frankenia pauciflora low open shrubland in swales
EC_DESC: Community occurs on Tamala South grey-brown sand, on mid to lower slopes of Tamala Limestone ridges and some isolated rises on calcareous deep and shallow sands. Taxa include Acacia rostellifera, Stylobasium spathulatum, Frankenia pauciflora, Tetragonia implexicoma, Threlkeldia diffusa, Zygophyllum fruticulosum.

EC_DESC:
Widely distributed, would need to clarify composition of herbs and extent of specific plant assemblage.
Similar assemblage occurs in the Pilbara.
