EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: unknown and poorly defined. ML: define by very little data, not thought to be distinct community type.
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: unknown and poorly defined. Mike Lyons: several wetlands east of Geraldton were surveyed as part of Carnarvon Basin survey, but not visited since.
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: unknown and poorly defined. ML: several wetlands east of Geraldton were surveyed as part of Carnarvon Basin survey, but not visited since.
EC_LISTINGREASON: P3 - iii) AOO large and/or EOO large with occurrences under threat across much of EOO, P3 - iii) AOO large and/or EOO large with occurrences under threat across much of EOO
EC_NOTES1: Mike Lyons: several wetlands in the northern wheatbelt (East of Geraldton) are dominated by Eucalyptus camaldulensis, with Coolibah (E. victrix). Surveyed as part of Carnarvon Basin Survey, E. victrix was recorded in a variety of wetlands but mostly river flooded flats and claypans occasisonally over lignum. Analysis defined assemblage as subtype (4a) in community type 4 in Gibson et al. (2000), however this was based on very little data and now not thought to be a valid community type. Suggest remove from PEC list.

Similar assemblage occurs in the Pilbara.

EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Geraldton Dist: unknown and poorly defined. ML: several wetlands east of Geraldton were surveyed as part of Carnarvon Basin survey, but not visited since.
EC_LISTINGREASON: P3 - iii) AOO large and/or EOO large with occurrences under threat across much of EOO, P3 - iii) AOO large and/or EOO large with occurrences under threat across much of EOO
EC_NOTES1: Mike Lyons: several wetlands in the northern wheatbelt (East of Geraldton) are dominated by Eucalyptus camaldulensis, with Coolibah (E. victrix). Surveyed as part of Carnarvon Basin Survey, E. victrix was recorded in a variety of wetlands but mostly river flooded flats and claypans occasisonally over lignum. Analysis defined assemblage as subtype (4a) in community type 4 in Gibson et al. (2000), however this was based on very little data and now not thought to be a valid community type. Suggest remove from PEC list.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Stirling Range Upland Yate woodlands
Stirling Range Upland Yate woodlands
Swamp Yate (Eucalyptus occidentalis) woodland in seasonally-inundated basins (South Coast)
EC_DESC:
This vegetation unit occurred frequently on the valley floor of the survey area as small, more-or-less
circular basins filled with clay that were inundated from winter until mid summer or longer (Figure 4.2).
The centre of these sumplands was usually inhabited by Swamp Yate (Eucalyptus occidentalis) low
woodland (Table 4.7, Plate 4.6) often with an understorey of the Saltwater Paperbark (Melaleuca
cuticularis). Peripheral to the central seasonally-inundated basin of these wetlands there was often a
waterlogged zone of E. occidentalis associated with Kunzea recurva heath to open scrub and/or the small
trees Melaleuca preissiana and Banksia littoralis and a number of mallees (primarily Eucalyptus
decipiens subsp. adesmophloia). Fringing the wetland there was usually an Anarthria laevis sedgeland.
However in the wetlands where there was shallow laterite, the sedgeland was usually replaced with a
Pericalymma ellipticum heath. The Swamp Yate was not present in Site 16; however the vegetation and
floristics of this wetland were otherwise very similar to that of the Swamp Yate sites.
The understorey shrubs of this vegetation were typically very open. Melaleuca cuticularis, Kunzea
recurva and Hakea nitida generally formed an open tall shrub layer. Hakea denticulata, Hakea laurina,
Hakea varia, Exocarpos sparteus, Agonis theiformis, Lambertia inermis and Nuytsia floribunda were also
sometimes present in the seasonally waterlogged areas fringing the sumplands. Other common shrub
taxa, recorded at low density across the sampled sites were Isopogon trilobus, Acacia pulchella var.
glaberrima, Taxandria spathulata, Astartea glomerosa, Astartea aspera, Beaufortia empetrifolia,
Melaleuca concinna and Conothamnus aureus. Other mid and low shrub species recorded at lower
abundance included Acacia biflora, Acacia luteola, A. subcaerulea, Adenanthos cuneatus, Banksia
baueri, Banksia dryandroides, Bossiaea praetermissa, Daviesia inflata, Dryandra falcata, Dryandra
mucronulata subsp. mucronulata, Dryandra tenuifolia var. tenuifolia, Gompholobium confertum,
Hibbertia lineata, Leucopogon conostephioides, Melaleuca subtrigona, Petrophile squamata subsp.
squamata, Petrophile media, Spyridium majoranifolium, Stirlingia anethifolia and Thomasia stelligera.
The perennial herbs Villarsia parnassifolia, Anthotium humile, Stylidium corymbosum, Goodenia
filiformis and Velleia trinervis were abundant in the wetlands in good condition. These herbs inhabited
the shallowly-inundated zone of the wetland and were most apparent when the water receded and the
herbs were in flower in late summer.
A dense ground layer was generally present in the seasonally waterlogged fringe of the sumplands and
this was dominated by rushes and sedges including Anarthria laevis, Baumea juncea, Gahnia
ancistrophylla, Lepidosperma striatum, Schoenus laevigatus, Schoenus subfascicularis and Tricostularia
compressa. A suite of native grasses was also recorded including Amphipogon amphipogonoides,
Austrostipa hemipogon, Cyperochloa hirsuta, Deyeuxia quadriseta and Neurachne alopecuroidea.
Naturalised alien grasses and herbs were prevalent in the more disturbed wetlands and these included
*Aira caryophyllea, *Cirsium vulgare, *Conyza parva, *Conyza sumatrensis, *Hordeum leporinum,
*Hypochaeris glabra, Juncus pallidus,*Lagurus ovatus, *Pennisetum clandestinum, *Pseudognaphalium
luteoalbum, *Rumex crispus, *Solanum nigrum and *Vulpia myuros var. megalura.
The mean species richness of these sites was 23.5 taxa per 10 m x 10 m quadrat, with a total of 166 taxa
recorded within the assemblage (including 24 naturalised alien taxa). One rare species, Commersonia sp.
Mt Groper R.G. Cranfield & D. Kabay (Sterculiaceae), that has been recently listed as Priority One Flora,
and one Priority 4 species, Goodenia filiformis (Goodeniaceae), were collected in this vegetation unit.

Scrub heath on Esperance Sandplain: Scrub heath on deep sand with Banksia and Lambertia, and Banksia scrub heath on sandplain.
EC_DESC: The scrub heath forms part of Beard’s (1979) Esperance System and comprises two very closely related vegetation units (bSZc & blSZc) on sand of varying depths overlying clay: Scrub heath dominated by Banksia speciosa and Lambertia inermis and other Proteaceous species such as B. media and Hakea spp. (with occasional Nuytsia floribunda and mallee species) over herbs on deep sand (to 1m) over clay over ironstone. The scrub heath may share a number of species in common with the Mallee heath vegetation unit (e26SZc) of the Esperance System: Eucalyptus tetragona and E. decipiens with occasional E. incrassata, E. redunca over Lambertia inermis and Hakea spp. on lateritic soil over ironstone.

Granite community dominated by the shrubs Calothamnus graniticus subsp. graniticus, Acacia cyclops, A. saligna, Hakea oleifolia, H. prostrata and Jacksonia furcellata (Sugar Loaf Rock)
EC_DESC: Shrubland (0.5-2 m) growing on shallow soils derived from granite gneiss on the Cowaramup and Gracetown (Willyabrup Exposed Rocky Slopes land unit) soil landscape systems. The dominant species include: Allocasuarina humilis, Acacia cyclops, A. littorea, A. pulchella, A. rostellifera, Calothamnus graniticus, Darwinia citriodora, Corymbia calophylla, Daviesia horrida, D. preissii, Dryandra lindleyana, D. erinacea, Hakea prostrata, H. trifurcata, Spyridium globulosum, Pimelea ferruginea, and Xanthorrhoea preissi.

Reedia spathacea - Empodisma gracillimum - Sporadanthus rivularis dominated floodplains and paluslopes of the Blackwood Plateau.
EC_DESC:
Diverse closed sedges and rushes to 1.5 m in height of Reedia spathacea/Empodisma gracillimum/Sporadanthus rivularis with open low shrubs to open scrub of Agonis linearifolia.  
Associates include: Acacia pulchella var. goadbyi, Actinotus laxus, Astartea aff. fascicularis, Baumea spp., Boronia fastigiata, Cyathochaeta teretifolia, Diaspasis filifolia, Drosera myriantha, Gymnoschoenus anceps, Leptocarpus tenax, Platychorda rivalis, Sporadanthus strictus, Utricularia paulineae, Xyris gracillima and Xyris maxima. Reedia spathacea is a major structural and possibly functional component of these wetlands and an indicator of specific wetland habitat (hydroperiod, water chemistry), vegetation floristics and condition. It is sensitive to severe or frequent fire and is preferentially grazed by feral pigs until virtual elimination from a site. These assemblages inhabit sandy mud floodplains and paluslopes of peat over mud of leptoscale river and creek tributaries of the Blackwood River which have perennially high water tables and only occur between Alexandra Bridge and Sues Rd on the Blackwood Plateau. The freshwater wetlands are unusual in this climatic region in that their high water tables are primarily maintained by artesian flow from the deep regional Leederville/Yaragadee aquifers.

Eucalyptus rudis, Corymbia calophylla, Agonis flexuosa Closed Low Forest (near Busselton)
EC_COMMUNITYID: Flooded gum, Marri and Peppermint Forest
EC_DESC: A low lying Spearwood Dune plant community associated with shallow sandy soils over Tamala limestone that in places is exposed at the surface. The plant community on these soils supports a unique mixture of wetland and upland flora. Typically low forest dominated by Eucalyptus rudis, Eucalyptus calophylla, Agonis flexuosa over a diverse understorey including Hibbertia hypericoides, Logania vaginalis, Conospermum caeruleum, Agrostocrinum hirsutum and Lomandra micrantha. Other associated species include Eucalyptus decipiens, Melaleuca rhaphiophylla, Banksia littoralis, Hakea varia and the sedge species Baumea juncea and Gahnia trifida (Webb et al 2009)

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Eucalyptus patens, Corymbia calophylla, Agonis flexuosa Closed Low Forest
EC_DESC: Eucalyptus patens on loamy brown sands over limestone. Species present include Eucalyptus patens, Corymbia calophylla and Agonis flexuosa over understorey species including Bossiaea linophylla, Hibbertia hypericoides, Gastrolobium praemorsum, Leucopogon propinquus, Phyllanthus calycinus, Lomandra micrantha, Lepidosperma longitudinale, Mesomelaena tetragona, Cyathochaeta avenacea and Tetraria octandra. The community is likely to have similarities to community type 1b ‘Southern Corymbia calophylla woodlands on heavy soils’.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Eucalyptus patens, Corymbia calophylla, Agonis flexuosa Closed Low Forest
Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
EC_DESC:
Virtually confined to the grey/white sands on the midslopes of the Whicher Scarp. Located on Whicher Scarp mid slopes. The taxa that identify the group include: Ricinocarpus aff. cyanescens, Hibbertia ferruginea, Platysace filiformis, Conospermum capitatum subsp. glabratum, Thysanotus arbuscular, Schoenus brevisetis, Phlebocarya filifolia, Leucopogon glabellus, Pimelea rosea subsp. rosea, Adenanthos obovatus, Stylidium carnosum and Gompholobium capitatum. 
Note: This community should be cross-referenced with ‘Eucalyptus haematoxylon - Eucalyptus marginata woodlands on Whicher foothills (‘community type 1a’)’
          
rarely associated with laterites. Mean native taxa 63.6. Mean weed taxa 1.3.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
EC_DESC:
Virtually confined to the grey/white sands on the midslopes of the Whicher Scarp. Located on Whicher Scarp mid slopes. The taxa that identify the group include: Ricinocarpus aff. cyanescens, Hibbertia ferruginea, Platysace filiformis, Conospermum capitatum subsp. glabratum, Thysanotus arbuscular, Schoenus brevisetis, Phlebocarya filifolia, Leucopogon glabellus, Pimelea rosea subsp. rosea, Adenanthos obovatus, Stylidium carnosum and Gompholobium capitatum. 
Note: This community should be cross-referenced with ‘Eucalyptus haematoxylon - Eucalyptus marginata woodlands on Whicher foothills (‘community type 1a’)’
          
rarely associated with laterites. Mean native taxa 63.6. Mean weed taxa 1.3.

Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
Central Whicher Scarp Mountain Marri woodland
West Whicher Scarp Banksia attenuata woodland (Swan Coastal Plain centred woodlands of grey/white sands community B2)
EC_DESC: This community type occurs in grey sand in the West Whicher Scarp. It is similar to the open Banksia attenuata woodlands with Peppermint (Agonis flexuosa) from the grey sands of the West Whicher Scarp. The type is species poor. Taxa include: Allocasuarina fraseriana, Banksia attenuata, Xylomellum occidentale, Bossiaea praetermissa, Calytrix flavescens, Gompholobium tomentosum, Hibbertia hypericoides, Hovea stricta, Hypocalymma robustum, Kunzea rostrata, Petrophile linearis and a suite of grasses, herbs and sedges. Swan Coastal Plain woodlands of grey/white sands. Formed from one grey sand quadrat from the West Whicher Scarp.  It is comparatively species poor. A significant number of the quadrats in group B1 as well as the B2 quadrat are in or adjacent to areas infected by dieback.

Shrublands of near permanent wetlands in creeklines of the Whicher Scarp (Whicher Scarp community G2)
EC_DESC: These shrublands are typically asociated with varying combinations of both common and uncommon sedges. Occasionally these swamps are associated with areas of ironstone such as observed in a Gale Road wetland. Poole Swamp in the Yelverton Forest is a typical example of these wetlands and was the largest area of this wetland community observed in the study.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Dardanup Jarrah and Mountain Marri woodland on laterite
EC_DESC: Located on an unusual surface of quartzite and laterite on the Dardanup forest which is an areas where the Whicher Scarp, Blackwood Plateau and Darling Scarp interface. Held together by two uncommonly encountered laterite species being Lomandra sp. Dardanup (G. J. Keighery 15065, Lomandra spartea, Olax benthamiana, Andersonia heterophylla, Hemigenia incana, Acacia varia var. varia, Daviesa angulata and Pimelea preissii and Lomandra brittanii, Xanthorrhoea acanthostachya, Dryandra armata var. armata, Hakea stenocarpa, Stachystemon vermicularis, Lambertia multiflora var. darlingensis, Petrophile striata and Pimelea sulphurea.

Sabina River Jarrah and Marri woodland (Whicher Scarp community F1)
EC_DESC: Community in Sabina River alluvial fan where the Sabina River meets the Swan Coastal Plain. It is characterised by a suite of wetland taxa of restricted occurrence in the Whicher Scarp: Mirbelia dilatata, Lomandra pauciflora, Tremandra diffusa, Tremandra stelligera, Trymalium floribundum subsp. trifidum and Clematis aristata var. occidentalis. Other significant taxa in the community are: Hovea elliptica, Leucopogon verticillatus, and Darwinia citriodora.

Melaleuca lanceolata forests, Leeuwin Naturaliste Ridge
EC_DESC: Low Closed Forest to Closed Forest of Melaleuca lanceolata ("moonah") occurring near the coastline of the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge adjacent to limestone cliffs and down steeply sloping rock slopes on dark-grey, brown or, less commonly, pale-grey sands, often with outcropping limestone.  The Moonah varies from 2 to 15 metres, reflecting depth of soil and wind pruning.  Typical understorey shrubs are Tetrogonia implexicoma, Rhagodia baccata, Leucopogon propinquus, and Suaeda australis
EC_KNOWNOCC_CAT: Greater than 20 (does not meet IUCN location criteria)
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Unknown
EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_NOTES: South West workshop: mapped occurrences are only 10-15m tree form of M. lanceolata
EC_EOOAREA_CAT: < 100,000ha (potentially meets extent of occurrence criteria for CR)
EC_EOOAREA_METHOD: Minimum convex polygon of records in DPaW corporate database
EC_EOOAREA_NOTES: South West workshop. S&C JAF02 5233ha + WAR01 12725ha
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: < 1,000ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for CR)
EC_DEGABIOTIC_RELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: South West workshop: no known abiotic
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: South West workshop: historical recreation & camping has cleared understory prior to last 10 years

EC_TENURE: Other crown reserves, Other public lands - roads and water bodies, DEC managed land - reserves IUCN I-IV

EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: SC i.b) Nomenclature
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: resolve community description
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_CAT: MD xii) Manage access
EC_MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI xii) Planning processes

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Low shrublands on acidic grey-brown sands of the Gracetown soil-landscape system
EC_DESC: A low shrubland or heath occurring on grey brown sand with a bleached surface derived from granite gneiss near the west coast of the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge. Dominant or characteristic shrub species inlcude; Calothamnus sanguineus, Darwinia citriodora, Hakea prostrata, Hakea trifurcata, Jacksonia horrida, Kunzea ciliata, Pimelea ferruginea, Pimelea rosea, Spyridium globulosum, Verticordia plumosa var. plumosa, Xanthorrhoea brunoniss. Common herbs, grasses and sedges inlcude; Asteridea pulverulenta, Austrodanthonia setacea, Austrostipa compressa, Brachyscome iberidifolia, Lepidosperma squamatum, Platysace haplosciadia, Trichocline spathulata and Velleia trinervis
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Unknown
EC_EOOAREA_NOTES: South West workshop: unknown. S&C calc 15ha
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: Unknown
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: South West workshop: all subject to trampling, drought stress

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Low shrublands on acidic grey-brown sands of the Gracetown soil-landscape system
Low shrublands on acidic grey-brown sands of the Gracetown soil-landscape system
EC_DESC: A low shrubland or heath occurring on grey brown sand with a bleached surface derived from granite gneiss near the west coast of the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge. Dominant or characteristic shrub species inlcude; Calothamnus sanguineus, Darwinia citriodora, Hakea prostrata, Hakea trifurcata, Jacksonia horrida, Kunzea ciliata, Pimelea ferruginea, Pimelea rosea, Spyridium globulosum, Verticordia plumosa var. plumosa, Xanthorrhoea brunoniss. Common herbs, grasses and sedges inlcude; Asteridea pulverulenta, Austrodanthonia setacea, Austrostipa compressa, Brachyscome iberidifolia, Lepidosperma squamatum, Platysace haplosciadia, Trichocline spathulata and Velleia trinervis

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Quindalup Eucalyptus gomphocephala and/or Agonis flexuosa woodlands
EC_DESC: This community is dominated by either Tuart or Agonis flexuosa. The presence of Hibbertia cuneiformis, Geranium retrorsum and Dichondra repens differentiate this group from other Quindalup community types. The type is found from the Leschenault Peninsular south to Busselton. Mean species richness: 37.6. Mean weed frequency 7.7.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Eucalyptus haematoxylon - E. marginata woodlands on Whicher foothills
EC_DESC: Occurs along the northern edge of state forest along the base of the Whicher Range and is composed of E. haematoxylon - Corymbia calophylla - E. marginata forest and woodlands. Taxa virtually restricted to the type include Acacia varia subsp varia, Agonis grandiflora and Xanthosa pusilla. Characterised by high frequency of species in Group S and moderate frequencies in species Group R. High mean soecies richness (67.6 species/plot). SCP1a had lower weed frequency (0.3 weeds/plot). Mean rainfall was high due to SCP1a's southern distribution.
EC_KNOWNOCC_CAT: Greater than 20 (does not meet IUCN location criteria)

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Southern Banksia attenuata woodlands
EC_DESC: This community is restricted to sand sheets at the base of the Whicher Scarp, the sand sheet on elevated ridges or the sand plain south of Bunbury. Structurally, this community type is normally Banksia attenuata or Eucalyptus marginata - B. attenuata woodlands. Common taxa include Acacia extensa, Jacksonia sp. Busselton, Laxmannia sessiliflora, Lysinema ciliatum and Johnsonia acaulis. Species richness averages 61.3 species/plot. Low mean weed frequency of 1.7.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Southern Banksia attenuata woodlands
Southern Banksia attenuata woodlands
Southern Banksia attenuata woodlands
Low lying Banksia attenuata woodlands or shrublands
EC_DESC: This type occurs sporadically between Gingin and Bunbury, and is largely restricted to the Bassendean system. The type tends to occupy lower lying wetter sites and is variously dominated by Melaleuca preissiana, B. attenuata, B. menziesii, Regelia ciliata, E. marginata, or Corymbia calophylla. Structurally this community type may be either a woodland or occasionally shrubland. Species richness of 40.5 and mean weed frequency of 3.6.

Epiphytic Cryptogams of the karri forest
EC_DESC: Cryptogams associated with Trymalium floribundum and Chorilaena quercifolia in the karri forests of south west WA. Epiphytic cryptogams of the Karri forests of south-west Western Australia: Comprises liverworts, mosses and lichens (see species list) found on the bark of mature (plants greater than 15 years old and prior to senescence at about age 50) Trymalium floribundum and Chorilaena quercifolia in the karri forest of s-w Western Australia. These communities are not fixed in space or time but exist in a state of dynamic equilibrium. They are dependent on a cycle of regeneration of host species adjacent to an existing site occupied by the community, these then persisting long enough for the community to migrate by spore or vegetative propagules onto the new hosts, this commencing at about ages 12-15 years. Some community members appear to have better dispersal mechanisms occurring more frequenetly in them than others while some are restricted and infrequent. These communiites occur in typically long unburnt pockets in the forest, usually in situations where high soil moisture and local high atmospheric humidity persists for most of the year. Natural fire incursions into these sites appear infrequent and provide the natural mosaic within them required for the community to persist. Most examples of this communiity now persist on senescent stands of Trymalium / Chorilaena in long unburnt areas with few mid age stand being found to be availabe to host it.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Dense heath B of Spyridium globulosum, Banksia occidentalis, Olearia axillaris, Melaleuca pauciflora, Pericalymma spongiocaule and Jacksonia horrida with tall open sedges of Ficinia nodosa
EC_DESC:
Typical species may include Anarthria prollifera, Ficinia nodosa, Baumea juncea, Hibbertia stellaris, Patersonia occidentalis, Cassytha racemosa, Melaleuca pauciflora, Melaleuca sp., Pericalymma spongiocaule, Banksia occidentalis, Hakea varia, Spyridium globulosum, Dodonaea ceratocarpa. Found at Black point, D’Entrecasteaux National Park
Threats: Uncontrolled vehicle access, trampling, grazing, altered hydrology, Phytophthora and acid sulphate soils.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Southwest Coastal Grassland
Southwest Coastal Grassland
Reedia spathacea - Empodisma gracillimum - Schoenus multiglumis dominated peat paluslopes and sandy mud floodplains of the Warren Biogeographical Region.
EC_DESC: Sedges/rushes to about 1.5m in height of Reedia spathacea/Empodisma gracillimum/Schoenus multiglumis with Homalospermum firmum low open shrubs to scrub. Common associates include: Acacia hastulata, Acidonia microcarpa, Actinotus laxus, Adenanthos obovatus, Boronia stricta, Cephalotus follicularis, Comesperma nudiusculum, Corybas abditus, Cosmelia  rubra ,Drosera hamiltonii, Gonocarpus simplex, Leucopogon australis, Leptocarpus tenax, Lycopodiella serpentina, Sphaerolobium rostratum, Sphenotoma gracile, Stylidium glaucum, Tetratheca filiformis, Utricularia paulineae and Xyris flexifolia. Less common associates are: Callistemon glaucus, Lepidosperma effusum and Rhadinothamnus anceps. Reedia spathacea is a major structural and possibly functional component of these wetlands and an indicator of specific wetland habitat (hydroperiod, water chemistry), vegetation floristics and condition. It is sensitive to severe or frequent fire and is preferentially grazed by feral pigs until virtual elimination from a site. A number of taxa endemic to the Warren Biogeographic Region and/or CALM Priority Species are concentrated in these wetlands including  Amperea protensa, Comesperma nudiusculum, Drosera binata, Drosera hamiltonii, Gonocarpus simplex, Schizaea rupestris, Schoenus multiglumis and Sphaerolobium rostratum. These assemblages inhabit paluslopes of peat over Tertiary coarse sand colluvium and sandy mud floodplains of leptoscale rivers and creeks. The perennially high water tables of these freshwater wetlands are primarily maintained by the humid climate, collection of rainwater from large natural catchment areas by subsurface flow into confined aquifers and water storage capacity of peat.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Reedia spathacea - Empodisma gracillimum - Schoenus multiglumis dominated peat paluslopes and sandy mud floodplains of the Warren Biogeographical Region.
Reedia spathacea - Empodisma gracillimum - Schoenus multiglumis dominated peat paluslopes and sandy mud floodplains of the Warren Biogeographical Region.
EC_DESC: Sedges/rushes to about 1.5m in height of Reedia spathacea/Empodisma gracillimum/Schoenus multiglumis with Homalospermum firmum low open shrubs to scrub. Common associates include: Acacia hastulata, Acidonia microcarpa, Actinotus laxus, Adenanthos obovatus, Boronia stricta, Cephalotus follicularis, Comesperma nudiusculum, Corybas abditus, Cosmelia  rubra ,Drosera hamiltonii, Gonocarpus simplex, Leucopogon australis, Leptocarpus tenax, Lycopodiella serpentina, Sphaerolobium rostratum, Sphenotoma gracile, Stylidium glaucum, Tetratheca filiformis, Utricularia paulineae and Xyris flexifolia. Less common associates are: Callistemon glaucus, Lepidosperma effusum and Rhadinothamnus anceps. Reedia spathacea is a major structural and possibly functional component of these wetlands and an indicator of specific wetland habitat (hydroperiod, water chemistry), vegetation floristics and condition. It is sensitive to severe or frequent fire and is preferentially grazed by feral pigs until virtual elimination from a site. A number of taxa endemic to the Warren Biogeographic Region and/or CALM Priority Species are concentrated in these wetlands including  Amperea protensa, Comesperma nudiusculum, Drosera binata, Drosera hamiltonii, Gonocarpus simplex, Schizaea rupestris, Schoenus multiglumis and Sphaerolobium rostratum. These assemblages inhabit paluslopes of peat over Tertiary coarse sand colluvium and sandy mud floodplains of leptoscale rivers and creeks. The perennially high water tables of these freshwater wetlands are primarily maintained by the humid climate, collection of rainwater from large natural catchment areas by subsurface flow into confined aquifers and water storage capacity of peat.

Basalt association of the Warren Region
EC_DESC:
Dwarf Scrub D Leucophyta brownii, Sarcocornia quinquefolia and Olearia axillaris with Open Low Sedges of Juncus pauciflorus and Herbs of Sarcocornia quinquefolia, Isolepis sp., Samolus repens and Very Open Low Grass of Sporobolus virginicus. Bunbury Basalt outcrops, flats over Bunbury Basalt with reddish brown sandy clay loam basaltic soils and basaltic saprolite outcrops with light yellowish brown clays.
Threats: Uncontrolled vehicle access, trampling, grazing, altered hydrology, Phytophthora and acid sulphate soils. Black Point - near Augusta Nominated due to the very limited occurrence of outcropping basalt and basalt soils in Western Australia.

EC_DESC: Species rich banksia woodlands on deep yellow-red sands that appear restricted to the western Dandaragan plateau (based on work by E.A. EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Claypans with mid dense shrublands of Melaleuca lateritia over herbs
EC_DESC: Claypans (predominantly basins) usually dominated by a shrubland of Melaleuca lateritia occurring both on the coastal plain and the adjacent plateau. These claypans are characterized by aquatic (Hydrocotyle lemnoides – P4) and amphibious taxa (e.g. Glossostigma diandrum, Villarsia capitata and Eleocharis keigheryi - R) (Gibson et al. 2005)

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Brackish microbial community number 1 (Government House, Rottnest)
EC_DESC:
About 10% of Rottnest Island is occupied by salt lakes, the deepest of which, Government House Lake, is up to 8.5m deep. The lakes have elongate-ovoid to sub-circular shapes, and are believed to overlie dolines formed by rainwater solution of the limestone and subsequent collapse of cave systems during Pleistocene periods of lower sea-level. The dolines were subsequently largely filled by Holocene sediments, and as sand dunes accumulated over the old karst surface. 

Water levels in the lakes rise to about mean sea-level in winter and fall more than a metre in summer as a result of evaporation. The larger lakes (including Government House Lake) commonly have late-summer salinities exceeding 150 000 mg/L. It is interesting that such high salinities can be maintained in the lakes when they are separated from the ocean by only narrow strips of porous limestone or sand. The explanation for this isolation of the hypersaline lake waters is believed to be the presence of impervious algal layers on the lake floors, which together with the muddy bottom sediments effectively seal the lakes. 

The three deeper lakes (including Government House Lake) become meramictic (“hot lakes”) during winter and spring, the bottom waters being up to 10°C warmer than the surface waters (Bunn and Edwards, 1984). The stratification of the water body that causes meromixis is due to fresh water from springs and rainfall spreading over the surface, above the heavier hypersaline lake water. This stratification is destroyed by evaporation and wind action during summer and autumn.

Modern salt lake deposits, consisting of algal, cyanobacterial, and evaporitic sediments, form veneers on the floors of the salt lakes and around their margins, overlying the Herschell and Tamala Limestones.

Hassell and Kneebone (1960) describe algal gyttja in the lake deposits. This consists largely of gel-like material from the green alga Botrycoccus (Hodgkin, 1959) mixed with gypsum and lime mud. Edward (1983) records benthic microbial mats up to 10cm thick on floors of the lakes, constructed by Botrycoccus and the cyanobacteria Aphanothecae halophytica, Oscillatoria sp., and Spirulina sp, together with the diatom Navicula sp. These mats from living stromatolites in a few areas, notably beside the old bathing groyne on the north side of Government House Lake.

Stromatolites occur on the shallow shelf immediately east of the groyne at depths (relative to summer water levels) of about 0.2m to 3m. Nodular branching columns and smooth undulous forms occur. Most are only about 5-10cm high, but some are as much as 20cm high. The stromatolites become progressively sparser in deeper water, and do not extend beyond depths of about 3m. Some grew on water-logged tree branches and other debris. Bubbles of oxygen, resulting from photosynthetic activity can be seen on the living microbial mats, which are greenish to yellow-grey and black in colour. 

From the thickness of stromatolites growing on old soft-drink bottles (brands that were current in the 1920s and 1930s when bathing in the hypersaline water was still fashionable) it is deduced that the stromatolites grow at rates of as much at 1.5mm per year.

From Playford et al 1988.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          From John et al (2009): The lake system has extensive benthic microbial communities (BMC) in the form of algal mats dominated in biomass by cyanobacteria. The BMC in Rottnest Island’s salt lakes have higher diversity and biomass of cyanobacteria than diatoms. Species of Aphanothece, Oscillatoria, Microcoleus, Spirulina, Schizothrix and Gloeocapsa are the common cyanobacteria in the BMC of Rottnest Island salt lakes.

Most are only about 5-10cm high, but some are as much as 20cm high. The stromatolites become progressively sparser in deeper water, and do not extend beyond depths of about 3m. Some grew on water-logged tree branches and other debris. Bubbles of oxygen, resulting from photosynthetic activity can be seen on the living microbial mats, which are greenish to yellow-grey and black in colour. 

From the thickness of stromatolites growing on old soft-drink bottles (brands that were current in the 1920s and 1930s when bathing in the hypersaline water was still fashionable) it is deduced that the stromatolites grow at rates of as much at 1.5mm per year.

From John et al (2009): The lake system has extensive benthic microbial communities (BMC) in the form of algal mats dominated in biomass by cyanobacteria. The BMC in Rottnest Island’s salt lakes have higher diversity and biomass of cyanobacteria than diatoms. Species of Aphanothece, Oscillatoria, Microcoleus, Spirulina, Schizothrix and Gloeocapsa are the common cyanobacteria in the BMC of Rottnest Island salt lakes.

Microbialites and microbial mats of coastal hypersaline lakes (Rottnest Island); Garden Lake
EC_DESC:
About 10% of Rottnest Island is occupied by salt lakes, the deepest of which, Government House Lake, is up to 8.5m deep. The lakes have elongate-ovoid to sub-circular shapes, and are believed to overlie dolines formed by rainwater solution of the limestone and subsequent collapse of cave systems during Pleistocene periods of lower sea-level. The dolines were subsequently largely filled by Holocene sediments, and as sand dunes accumulated over the old karst surface. 

Water levels in the lakes rise to about mean sea-level in winter and fall more than a metre in summer as a result of evaporation. The larger lakes (including Government House Lake) commonly have late-summer salinities exceeding 150 000 mg/L. It is interesting that such high salinities can be maintained in the lakes when they are separated from the ocean by only narrow strips of porous limestone or sand. The explanation for this isolation of the hypersaline lake waters is believed to be the presence of impervious algal layers on the lake floors, which together with the muddy bottom sediments effectively seal the lakes. 

The three deeper lakes (including Government House Lake) become meramictic (“hot lakes”) during winter and spring, the bottom waters being up to 10°C warmer than the surface waters (Bunn and Edwards, 1984). The stratification of the water body that causes meromixis is due to fresh water from springs and rainfall spreading over the surface, above the heavier hypersaline lake water. This stratification is destroyed by evaporation and wind action during summer and autumn.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Microbialites and microbial mats of coastal hypersaline lakes (Rottnest Island); Herschel Lake
Microbialites and microbial mats of coastal hypersaline lakes (Rottnest Island); Herschel Lake
EC_DESC:
About 10% of Rottnest Island is occupied by salt lakes, the deepest of which, Government House Lake, is up to 8.5m deep. The lakes have elongate-ovoid to sub-circular shapes, and are believed to overlie dolines formed by rainwater solution of the limestone and subsequent collapse of cave systems during Pleistocene periods of lower sea-level. The dolines were subsequently largely filled by Holocene sediments, and as sand dunes accumulated over the old karst surface. 

Water levels in the lakes rise to about mean sea-level in winter and fall more than a metre in summer as a result of evaporation. The larger lakes (including Government House Lake) commonly have late-summer salinities exceeding 150 000 mg/L. It is interesting that such high salinities can be maintained in the lakes when they are separated from the ocean by only narrow strips of porous limestone or sand. The explanation for this isolation of the hypersaline lake waters is believed to be the presence of impervious algal layers on the lake floors, which together with the muddy bottom sediments effectively seal the lakes. 

The three deeper lakes (including Government House Lake) become meramictic (“hot lakes”) during winter and spring, the bottom waters being up to 10°C warmer than the surface waters (Bunn and Edwards, 1984). The stratification of the water body that causes meromixis is due to fresh water from springs and rainfall spreading over the surface, above the heavier hypersaline lake water. This stratification is destroyed by evaporation and wind action during summer and autumn.

Modern salt lake deposits, consisting of algal, cyanobacterial, and evaporitic sediments, form veneers on the floors of the salt lakes and around their margins, overlying the Herschell and Tamala Limestones.

Hassell and Kneebone (1960) describe algal gyttja in the lake deposits. This consists largely of gel-like material from the green alga Botrycoccus (Hodgkin, 1959) mixed with gypsum and lime mud. Edward (1983) records benthic microbial mats up to 10cm thick on floors of the lakes, constructed by Botrycoccus and the cyanobacteria Aphanothecae halophytica, Oscillatoria sp., and Spirulina sp, together with the diatom Navicula sp. These mats from living stromatolites in a few areas, notably beside the old bathing groyne on the north side of Government House Lake.

Stromatolites occur on the shallow shelf immediately east of the groyne at depths (relative to summer water levels) of about 0.2m to 3m. Nodular branching columns and smooth undulous forms occur. Most are only about 5-10cm high, but some are as much as 20cm high. The stromatolites become progressively sparser in deeper water, and do not extend beyond depths of about 3m. Some grew on water-logged tree branches and other debris. Bubbles of oxygen, resulting from photosynthetic activity can be seen on the living microbial mats, which are greenish to yellow-grey and black in colour. 

From the thickness of stromatolites growing on old soft-drink bottles (brands that were current in the 1920s and 1930s when bathing in the hypersaline water was still fashionable) it is deduced that the stromatolites grow at rates of as much at 1.5mm per year.

From Playford et al 1988.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          From John et al (2009): The lake system has extensive benthic microbial communities (BMC) in the form of algal mats dominated in biomass by cyanobacteria. The BMC in Rottnest Island’s salt lakes have higher diversity and biomass of cyanobacteria than diatoms. Species of Aphanothece, Oscillatoria, Microcoleus, Spirulina, Schizothrix and Gloeocapsa are the common cyanobacteria in the BMC of Rottnest Island salt lakes.

Edward (1983) records benthic microbial mats up to 10cm thick on floors of the lakes, constructed by Botrycoccus and the cyanobacteria Aphanothecae halophytica, Oscillatoria sp., and Spirulina sp, together with the diatom Navicula sp. These mats from living stromatolites in a few areas, notably beside the old bathing groyne on the north side of Government House Lake.

Stromatolites occur on the shallow shelf immediately east of the groyne at depths (relative to summer water levels) of about 0.2m to 3m. Nodular branching columns and smooth undulous forms occur. Most are only about 5-10cm high, but some are as much as 20cm high. The stromatolites become progressively sparser in deeper water, and do not extend beyond depths of about 3m. Some grew on water-logged tree branches and other debris. Bubbles of oxygen, resulting from photosynthetic activity can be seen on the living microbial mats, which are greenish to yellow-grey and black in colour. 

From the thickness of stromatolites growing on old soft-drink bottles (brands that were current in the 1920s and 1930s when bathing in the hypersaline water was still fashionable) it is deduced that the stromatolites grow at rates of as much at 1.5mm per year.

From Playford et al 1988.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          From John et al (2009): The lake system has extensive benthic microbial communities (BMC) in the form of algal mats dominated in biomass by cyanobacteria. The BMC in Rottnest Island’s salt lakes have higher diversity and biomass of cyanobacteria than diatoms. Species of Aphanothece, Oscillatoria, Microcoleus, Spirulina, Schizothrix and Gloeocapsa are the common cyanobacteria in the BMC of Rottnest Island salt lakes.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Microbialites and microbial mats of coastal hypersaline lakes (Rottnest Island); Vincent Lake
Microbialites and microbial mats of coastal hypersaline lakes (Rottnest Island); Vincent Lake
EC_DESC:
About 10% of Rottnest Island is occupied by salt lakes, the deepest of which, Government House Lake, is up to 8.5m deep. The lakes have elongate-ovoid to sub-circular shapes, and are believed to overlie dolines formed by rainwater solution of the limestone and subsequent collapse of cave systems during Pleistocene periods of lower sea-level. The dolines were subsequently largely filled by Holocene sediments, and as sand dunes accumulated over the old karst surface. 

Water levels in the lakes rise to about mean sea-level in winter and fall more than a metre in summer as a result of evaporation. The larger lakes (including Government House Lake) commonly have late-summer salinities exceeding 150 000 mg/L. It is interesting that such high salinities can be maintained in the lakes when they are separated from the ocean by only narrow strips of porous limestone or sand. The explanation for this isolation of the hypersaline lake waters is believed to be the presence of impervious algal layers on the lake floors, which together with the muddy bottom sediments effectively seal the lakes. 

The three deeper lakes (including Government House Lake) become meramictic (“hot lakes”) during winter and spring, the bottom waters being up to 10°C warmer than the surface waters (Bunn and Edwards, 1984). The stratification of the water body that causes meromixis is due to fresh water from springs and rainfall spreading over the surface, above the heavier hypersaline lake water. This stratification is destroyed by evaporation and wind action during summer and autumn.

Modern salt lake deposits, consisting of algal, cyanobacterial, and evaporitic sediments, form veneers on the floors of the salt lakes and around their margins, overlying the Herschell and Tamala Limestones.

Hassell and Kneebone (1960) describe algal gyttja in the lake deposits. This consists largely of gel-like material from the green alga Botrycoccus (Hodgkin, 1959) mixed with gypsum and lime mud. Edward (1983) records benthic microbial mats up to 10cm thick on floors of the lakes, constructed by Botrycoccus and the cyanobacteria Aphanothecae halophytica, Oscillatoria sp., and Spirulina sp, together with the diatom Navicula sp. These mats from living stromatolites in a few areas, notably beside the old bathing groyne on the north side of Government House Lake.

Stromatolites occur on the shallow shelf immediately east of the groyne at depths (relative to summer water levels) of about 0.2m to 3m. Nodular branching columns and smooth undulous forms occur. Most are only about 5-10cm high, but some are as much as 20cm high. The stromatolites become progressively sparser in deeper water, and do not extend beyond depths of about 3m. Some grew on water-logged tree branches and other debris. Bubbles of oxygen, resulting from photosynthetic activity can be seen on the living microbial mats, which are greenish to yellow-grey and black in colour. 

From the thickness of stromatolites growing on old soft-drink bottles (brands that were current in the 1920s and 1930s when bathing in the hypersaline water was still fashionable) it is deduced that the stromatolites grow at rates of as much at 1.5mm per year.

From Playford et al 1988.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          From John et al (2009): The lake system has extensive benthic microbial communities (BMC) in the form of algal mats dominated in biomass by cyanobacteria. The BMC in Rottnest Island’s salt lakes have higher diversity and biomass of cyanobacteria than diatoms. Species of Aphanothece, Oscillatoria, Microcoleus, Spirulina, Schizothrix and Gloeocapsa are the common cyanobacteria in the BMC of Rottnest Island salt lakes.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Banksia ilicifolia woodlands, southern Swan Coastal Plain (‘community type 22’)
EC_DESC: Low lying sites generally consisting of Banksia ilicifolia – B. attenuata woodlands, but Melaleuca preissiana woodlands and scrubs are also recorded. Occurs on Bassendean and Spearwood systems in the central Swan Coastal Plain north of Rockingham. Typically has very open understorey, and sites are likely to be seasonally waterlogged. Low species richness (mean 32.5).

Swan Coastal Plain Banksia attenuata - Banksia menziesii woodlands
Swan Coastal Plain Banksia attenuata - Banksia menziesii woodlands
EC_DESC: Occur in the Bassendean system from Melaleuca Park to Gingin. Quite rare. Has a mostly northern distribution and is characterised by high frequencies of species in Group N. Lower species richness than subgroup 23a (53.8) and significantly lower mean weed frequency (0.7 species/plot).

Microbial community of a coastal saline lake (Lake Walyungup)
EC_DESC: Microbial community consisting of microbial mats and variously shaped solid stromatolite-like structures (pustular mats, nodules, large columnar structures to 1.2m high) around the edges of two separate water bodies (north and south) collectively known as Lake Walyungup. Lake Walyungup is a saline coastal lake surrounded by various woodlands and sedgelands.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Yellow Sandplain Communities of the Great Victoria Desert
EC_DESC: Undulating yellow sandplain with an open upper stratum of marble gum (Eucalyptus gongylocarpa), with or without a diverse mallee stratum (dominated by Eucalyptus mannensis, E. undulans, E. youngiana, E. platycorys); a sparse though diverse shrub stratum (Acacia heteroneura, A. helmsiana, Allocasuarina acutivalvis, Bertya dimerostigma and Hakea francisiana);with an understorey of Triodia desertorum or T. scariosa. The soils are typically yellow-orange deep Quaternary aeolian sands or sandy loams. Very high small vertebrate diversity (most species of terrestrial reptile and mammal species per hectare known (D. Pearson pers. comm.)), unusual combinations of species (mixture of SW and arid), high numbers of threatened species (mulgara, marsupial mole, sandhill dunnart, woma python, mallee fowl, scarlet-chested and princess parrots, pink cockatoo etc.) and hot spot for mallee-eucalypt species as well as other rare/poorly known plant species.
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Static (no change)
EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Expert opinion
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: < 1,000,000ha (does not meet IUCN area of occupancy criteria)
EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: JM: I summed area of occupancy from subregions
EC_LISTINGREASON: P3 - ii) occurrences few but EOO large with either large AOO or large areas of habitat where occurrences likely and most not under immediate threat
EC_TENURE: DEC managed land - reserves IUCN I-IV, Unallocated crown land
EC_NOTES1: V. English quick survey of condition. Dave Pearson Masters Thesis
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: QTP i) Quantifying threatening processes – landscapes
EC_MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: Determine appropriate fire regime
EC_MANREQ_EVALUATION: EV iv) Develop/implement monitoring and evaluation and reporting plan
EC_MANREQ_CONSPLAN_CAT: CP viii) Reserve area plan (DPaW tenure only; specify)
EC_MANREQ_DIRECT_CAT: MD i) Fire management for biodiversity (specify)
EC_MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI xi) Regulation - environmental impact assessment
EC_NOTES2: Queen Victoria Spring Nature Reserve.  Very small section of PEC in MUR01 but data calculated on GVD01 and GVD02 only.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Lignum-canegrass shrubland
EC_DESC: Shrubland dominated by lignum Muehlenbeckia cunninghamii,with some canegrass Eragrostis australiasica.  Thundelarra Lignum Swamp supports a significant example of this lignum-canegrass community, which in Western Australia occurs very sparsely, mainly from north of Carnarvon to east of Kalgoorlie.  Widely distributed, would need to clarify composition of herbs and extent of specific plant assemblage. Similar assemblage occurs in the Pilbara.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Parker Range vegetation complexes
EC_DESC: Eucalyptus sheathiana with E. transcontinentalis and/or E. eremophila woodland on sandy soils at the base of ridges and low rises; E. longicornis with E. corrugata and E. salubris or E. myridena woodland on broad flats; E. salmonophloia and E. salubris woodland on broad flats; Allocasuarina acutivalvis and A. corniculata on deeper sandy soils of lateritic ridges; E. capillosa subsp. polyclada and/or E. loxophleba over Hakea pendens thicket on skeletal soils on ridges (laterites, breakaways and massive gossanous caps); and Callitris glaucophylla low open woodland on massive greenstone ridges.

Salt Flats Plant Assemblages of the Mortlock River (East Branch)
EC_DESC: The habitat comprises braided channels (up to 2 km wide), flats, wash-lines and sandy rises (up to 2m high) stretching 39 km along the Mortlock River (East) from Meckering eastwards to 8 km west of Tammin. A mosaic of plant communities assorted by elevation occurs on the river flats. The area represents the most extensive braided saline drainage line in this part of the SW agricultural zone. The plant community comprises mixed shrubs (Scholtzia capitata, Melaleuca aff. uncinata) over species rich herbs on sandy rises, with Melaleuca thyoides margins., dwarf scrub and species rich herbs on washlines and saline wetlands.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Natural organic saline seeps of the Avon Botanical District
EC_DESC: This community is characterised by vegetation in a series of bands from the upland to the saline seep. 1) Dunes and Sandplain: The surrounding sand dunes are covered in a woodland of Eucalyptus loxophleba subsp. Lissophloia and E. hypochlamydea or Banksia prionotes. On lower dunes a shrubland of M. lateriflora subsp. Lateriflora, M. hamulosa and Scholtzia capitata occurs. Adjacent to the seep are shrublands or low woodlands of Melaleuca cuticularis and M. thyoides over succulent shrublands of Sarcocornia quinqueflora 2) Saline seep: Dense succulent shrubland of Sarcocornia quinqueflora, Halosarcia halocnemoides and Wilsonia backhousei with scattered sedges of Juncus kraussii subsp. Australiensis and shrubs of Frankenia pauciflora (Slender Inland) on a quaking deep organic substrate. 3). Adjacent flats and flow lines dominated by microbial mats with scattered shrubs of Sarcocornia quinqueflora and Wilsonia backhousei and saline aquatics of Ruppia megacarpa and Lepilaena preissii. 4) Along the margins of the creek there are also sandy rises dominated by succulent shrublands of Halosarcia spp.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Triodia angusta dominated creekline vegetation (Barrow Island)
Coastal dune tussock grassland dominated by Whiteochloa airoides
EC_DESC:
Tussock grassland of Whiteochloa airoides on hind dunes or remnant dunes with white or pinkish white medium sands with marine fragments. There may be occasional Spinifex longifolius tussock or Triodia epactia hummock grasses. There may be scattered low shrubs of Olearia dampierii subsp. dampierii, Scaevola spinescens, S. cunninghamii, Trianthema turgidifolia and Corchorus species. Occurs on Barrow Island and possibly some unaffected littoral areas in West Pilbara.
Threats: weed invasion especially buffel grass and kapok, basic raw material extraction.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Coastal dune tussock grassland dominated by Whiteochloa airoides
Cape Range Remipede Community
EC_DESC:
An anchialine habitat with a rich troglobitic fauna composed primarily of crustaceans, but including two blind fishes (Humphreys and Adams 1991; Poore and Humphreys 1992; Bruce and Humphreys 1993; Humphreys 1993a). The faunal composition consists of the same groups of crustaceans recorded from anchialine caves of the Bahamas, the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico, and Cuba (Yager 1987a, 1987b, 1994). They include cirolanid isopods, atyid shrimp, ostracodes, gammarid amphipods, remipedes and thermosbaenaceans. 
This aquatic community composition has become predictable in anchialine habitats on either side of the North Atlantic (Holsinger 1989, 1992; Yager 1994), and the occurrence of additional relict taxa in northwestern Australia was predicted (Humphreys 1993a) owing to the presence of thermosbaenaceans (Poore and Humphreys 1992) and cirolanids (Humphreys 1993a).

The remipede community  is known only from Bundera Sinkhole (C-28), an anchialine cave on the western side of the Cape Range peninsula where it occurs below a pycnocline and comprises an assemblage of native species endemic to northwestern Australia, several known only from this site while others are more widespread on the fringes of the North West Shelf. It contains a number of species unique to that site and others unique to the fringes of the North West Shelf.  These include:-
Lasionectes exleyi Yager and Humphreys  (Remipedia)
Liagoceradocus branchialis  Bradbury and Williams (Crustacea: Hadziida)
Danielopolina undescribed species (Baltanas et al.,  in prep)(Ostracoda: Halocyprida: Thaumatocyprididae)
Stygiocaris stylifera Holthuis (Decapoda: Natantia: Atyidae)
Milyeringa veritas Whitely  (Perciformes: Eleotridae)

This is a recognised community in anchialine water occurring below a strong density interface (Yager et al. 1994; Iliffe 1987, 1992; Sket, 1981, 1996; Pohlman et al. 1997) and in anoxic conditions with hydrogen sulphide layers in mid-water (W.F. Humphreys, unpublished data).

The remipede community predominantly comprised species congeneric with those occurring in similar habitats on either side of the North Atlantic.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Camerons Cave Troglobitic Community
EC_DESC:
A troblobitic (obligatory cave inhabitants) community inhabiting the coastal plain of the Cape Range peninsula. The community is known only from Camerons Cave (C-452)  in the Exmouth townsite.

The species assemblage is related to that found in caves in Cape Range sensu stricto (papers in Humphreys, 1993), but is quite distinct from it.  Most of the troglobitic species found there  are known from nowhere else.   These include:-

• Stygiochiropus peculiaris Shear and Humphreys (Diplopoda: Polydesmida: Paradoxosomatidae Australiosomatinae: Antichiropodini):
only known from six specimens (2 collected dead) from C-452. Three other species of the genus, which is endemic to Cape Range (Humphreys and Shear,  1993; Shear and Humphreys, 1996), occur in Cape Range sensu stricto.

• Hyella sp. nov. (Pseudoscorpionida: Hyidae): only known from the dark zone of C-452 from 4 female and one adult male specimens plus 5 immature. Specimens BES 2545;  2546;  2554; 4249;  4148; 4149;  4154;  1154;  2525. Another species of the genus, which is endemic to Cape Range (Harvey, 1993) occurs in Cape Range sensu stricto.

• An undescribed species of troglomorphic  harvestmen (Opilionida: Assamiidae)— specimens BES 2549; 4189.

• An undescribed species of troglomorphic  harvestmen (Opilionida: Phalangodidae) is only known specimen of the family Phalangodidae from Cape Range— specimen BES 2543. 

• An undescribed troglomorphic species of cave spider (Hahniidae: Araneae), known from one specimen —BES 1155. A related troglomorphic species is known from caves in Cape Range proper.

• Phaconura sp. nov. (Hemiptera: Meenoplidae), troglomorphic (H. Hoch, pers. comm.), very different from all other Phaconeura—BES 2544 . Know only from C-452.  Another species of Phaconeura occurs in caves in Cape Range proper (Hoch, 1993).

• An undescribed troglomorphic species of cave spider (Ctenidae: Araneae) known from three specimen, all juvenile —BES 2526; 2539; 2541. Related epigean and troglobitic species are known from Cape Range proper (Harvey et al. 1993).

• Draculoides bramstokeri Harvey and Humphreys (Schizomida: Hubbardiidae) is troglobitic and occurs in the cave.  This species is known from one other location in Exmouth and from Barrow Island (Harvey and Humphreys 1995).  Several other species of Schizomida are known from Cape Range caves both from the coastal plain and the range proper, mostly troglomorphic (Harvey et al. 1993; M.S. Harvey, pers. comm.).

• Trichocyclus sp. (Pholcidae: Araneae).  Species presently uncertain; known from three specimens —BES 2021; 4248.


To date all species with congeneric members in caves in Cape Range proper have proved to be quite distinct species. This cave community is recognisable by its unique composition of species of which at least • are known only from this location.


Associated Fauna
Other fauna whose status is unknown, probably epigean, occur in C-452 including:

Isopoda: Oniscoidea: Armadillidae    
Ploiaria sp.1 (Hemiptera: Reduviidae: Emesinae)
? Centrogonus sp.  (Hemiptera: Reduviidae: Emesinae)
Coleoptera: Trogidae    
Blattodea     
Collembola     
     
C-452 also contains an aquatic fauna including Milyeringa veritas (troglomorphic) and Copepoda: Calanoida.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Barrow Island stygofauna and troglofauna
Subterranean invertebrate community of pisolitic hills in the Pilbara
EC_DESC: A series of low undulating hills (Mesa H, Todd Bore and Warramboo) occurring in the Robe Valley near Pannawonica in the Shire of Ashburton in the State's Pilbara Region.  The hills are remnants of old valley infill deposits of the palaeo Robe River. Pisolite is made up of spherical accretions of iron minerals called pisoliths (the iron ore source), which often have small caverns and spaces between them. These interstices can be large enough to accommodate troglobitic fauna (Biota 2006C). Troglobitic faunal communities occurs in extremely specialised habitats and appear to require the particular structure and hydrogeology associated with mesas (but also apparently with other ironstone hills in the Robe Valley Region - Biota 2006A) to provide a suitable humid habitat (EPA 2007). Specifically, the habitat is the humidified pisolitic strata (small round accretionary masses of rock). These troglobitic communities are believed to be relics of the late Miocene (23 to 5.3 million years BP), having arisen from tropical faunal lineages that descended into subterranean environments during the aridification of Australia (Biota 2006A). Short range endemism is common in these fauna (Biota 2006A). Eleven fauna taxa located in Mesa A, for example, was not located in any other mesa sampled. This high level of endemicity was the general pattern of distribution noted by Biota (2006A) for mesas and other hills in the Robe Valley that were thought to be likely habitat for troglofauna.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Subterranean invertebrate communities of mesas in the Robe Valley region
EC_DESC:
Subterranean invertebrate communities of a series of isolated pisolitic mesas in the Robe Valley near Pannawonica in the Shire of Ashburton in the State's Pilbara Region.  Includes Mesa A, B, C, G and K and mesas not yet surveyed.  The mesas are remnants of old valley infill deposits of the palaeo Robe River.  Mesas are flat topped hills with a hard laterised goethite cap (Biota 2006A).The cap is underlain by pisolite which is made up of spherical accretions of iron minerals called pisoliths (the iron ore source), which often have small caverns and spaces between them. These interstices can be large enough to accommodate troglobitic fauna (Biota 2006C). It is assumed that the other ironstone hills also provide a similar habitat for troglobitic fauna that were located in these hills by Biota (2006A).

Troglobitic faunal communities occurs in extremely specialised habitats and appear to require the particular structure and hydrogeology associated with mesas (but also apparently with other ironstone hills in the Robe Valley Region - Biota 2006A) to provide a suitable humid habitat (EPA 2007). Specifically, the habitat is the humidified pisolitic strata (small round accretionary masses of rock). These troglobitic communities are believed to be relics of the late Miocene (23 to 5.3 million years BP), having arisen from tropical faunal lineages that descended into subterranean environments during the aridification of Australia (Biota 2006A). Short range endemism is common in these fauna (Biota 2006A). Eleven fauna taxa located in Mesa A, for example, was not located in any other mesa sampled. This high level of endemicity was the general pattern of distribution noted by Biota (2006A) for mesas and other hills in the Robe Valley that were thought to be likely habitat for troglofauna.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Stygofaunal communities of the Western Fortescue Plains freshwater aquifer
EC_DESC: A unique assemblage of subterranean invertebrate fauna, characterised by Spelaeogripaceans, occupies the freshwater Millstream aquifer in the Pilbara (CALM 1998).  In 1997 Spelaeogriphacea, a new order of crustaceans for Australia, was identified from the Millstream aquifer. It appears that this lineage may have already been in freshwater prior to the dissolution of the supercontinent Pangaea and long before the fragmentation of Gondwana. The associated fauna includes Oligochaeta: Phreodrilidae (generally with a cool climate Gondwanan distribution : A. Pinder, pers. comm., 1997); *Gastropoda: new hydrobioid (W.F. Ponder, pers. comm., 1997); *Syncarida: Bathynellacea; *Copepoda: Cyclopoidea (2+ species); Copepoda: Harpacticoidea; *Ostracoda ( 3  species of  Candonidae: I. Karanovic, pers. comm.); *Isopoda: Phreatoicidea (Pilbarophreatoicus sp. nov., G.F. Wilson, pers. comm. 1996); *Amphipoda: Crangonyctoidea (does not align with known groups, J. EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Aquatic Root Mat Community Number 1 of Caves of the Leeuwin Naturaliste Ridge
EC_DESC:
The four originally described root mat communities occur separately in Easter and Jewel Caves (this TEC), Strongs Cave, Calgardup Cave, and Kudjal Yolgah and Budjur Mar Caves on the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge. Species composition of the community in each of these cave systems differs significantly. Each community is described as comprising a complete food web; the rootlets and their associated microflora providing the primary food source, and root mat grazers, predators, parasites, detritivores, and scavengers completing the interactions. The root mats are produced by karri (Eucalyptus diversicolor) in Easter Cave. Aquatic cavernicoles (cave animals) in these communities include koonacs (Cherax preissii), other crustaceans, mites, rotifers, microscopic worms, tardigrades, and insects and crustaceans. Some of the species appear to be endemic to these cave systems, and some to be confined to a single cave.Easter and Jewel Caves are both Augusta watertable caves and part of the Jewel Cave karst system (sensu Eberhard 2004) and linked hydrologically. The two caves are therefore mapped as one occurrence of the TEC. The fauna of these two caves share three species, all of which are endemic to this karst system. Thus, the new root mat assemblages found in these caves are clearly new areas of the known root mat community number 1. 

A possible additional occurrence of root mat community no. 1 may have occurred in Labyrinth Cave, a different sub-system, but which Eberhard (2004) defines as also part of the Jewel Cave karst system. The only stygofaunal species collected from Labyrinth Cave (Uroctena n.sp., a stygobitic amphipod) is shared with the two other Augusta watertable caves (and was collected nowhere else). However, Labyrinth Cave is now dry.
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Loss of occurrences (pressures > recovery actions)
EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
EC_KNOWNOCC_NOTES: South West Region & Eberhard 2010: Easter and Jewel caves, linked hydrologically and therefore 1 occurrence. In Jewel Cave and Labyrinth Cave, all known habitat and occurrences of Aquatic Root Community No. 1 have dried-up and been lost, and In Easter Cave (including the TEC type locality - Tiffanys Lake), more than 98% of known habitat area and occurrences have been lost (Eberhard 2010). Possible loss of occurrence at Labyrinth Cave? Now dry.
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: < 1ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for CR)
EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: Eberhard 2010: very small pools remain, several square metres.
EC_DEGABIOTIC_RELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: South West Region & Eberhard 2010: groundwater levels declined by 1m, measured at Labrynthe

EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: South West Region & Eberhard 2010: pools that root mats grow in have dried up, loss of at least 2 endemic species

EC_TENURE: DEC managed land - reserves IUCN I-IV
EC_NOTES1: Eberhard 2010 report on this occurrence

EC_KNOWNOCC_NOTES: South West Region & Eberhard 2010: Easter and Jewel caves, linked hydrologically and therefore 1 occurrence. In Jewel Cave and Labyrinth Cave, all known habitat and occurrences of Aquatic Root Community No. 1 have dried-up and been lost, and In Easter Cave (including the TEC type locality - Tiffanys Lake), more than 98% of known habitat area and occurrences have been lost (Eberhard 2010). Possible loss of occurrence at Labyrinth Cave? Now dry.

EC_DESC: The four originally described root mat communities occur separately in Easter and Jewel Caves, Strongs Cave (this TEC), Calgardup Cave, and Kudjal Yolgah and Budjur Mar Caves on the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge. Species composition of the community in each of these cave systems differs significantly. Each community is described as comprising a complete food web; the rootlets and their associated microflora providing the primary food source, and root mat grazers, predators, parasites, detritivores, and scavengers completing the interactions. The root mats are produced by karri (Eucalyptus diversicolor) in Easter Cave and Strongs Cave. Aquatic cavernicoles (cave animals) in these communities include koonacs (Cherax preissii), other crustaceans, mites, rotifers, microscopic worms, tardigrades, and insects and crustaceans. Some of the species appear to be endemic to these cave systems, and some to be confined to a single cave.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Aquatic Root Mat Community Number 3 of Caves of the Leeuwin Naturaliste Ridge
EC_DESC: The four originally described root mat communities occur separately in Easter and Jewel Caves, Strongs Cave, Calgardup Cave, and Kudjal Yolgah and Budjur Mar Caves (this TEC) on the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge. Species composition of the community in each of these cave systems differs significantly. Each community is described as comprising a complete food web; the rootlets and their associated microflora providing the primary food source, and root mat grazers, predators, parasites, detritivores, and scavengers completing the interactions. The root mats are produced by karri and peppermint (Agonis flexuosa) in Kudjal Yolgah Cave. Aquatic cavernicoles (cave animals) in these communities include koonacs (Cherax preissii), other crustaceans, mites, rotifers, microscopic worms, tardigrades, and insects and crustaceans. Some of the species appear to be endemic to these cave systems, and some to be confined to a single cave.  The data of Eberhard (2004) show that Budjur Mar and Kudjul Yolgah caves are in the same karst drainage system, and share four species not found elsewhere. Thus, the root mat assemblage of Budjur Mar cave is identified as an additional occurrence of aquatic root mat community no. 3 rather than a new community.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Aquatic Root Mat Community Number 4 of Caves of the Leeuwin Naturaliste Ridge
EC_DESC: The four originally described root mat communities occur separately in Easter and Jewel Caves, Strongs Cave, Calgardup Cave (this TEC), and Kudjal Yolgah and Budjur Mar Caves on the Leeuwin-Naturaliste Ridge. Species composition of the community in each of these cave systems differs significantly. Each community is described as comprising a complete food web; the rootlets and their associated microflora providing the primary food source, and root mat grazers, predators, parasites, detritivores, and scavengers completing the interactions. The root mats are produced by marri (Corymbia calophylla) in Calgardup Cave. Aquatic cavernicoles (cave animals) in these communities include koonacs (Cherax preissii), other crustaceans, mites, rotifers, microscopic worms, tardigrades, and insects and crustaceans. Some of the species appear to be endemic to these cave systems, and some to be confined to a single cave.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Casuarina obesa Association
Elongate Fluviatile Delta System - Peel-Harvey inlet
EC_DESC: Houses a wide range of wetland habitats along the 2.5km delta formation. Vegetation comprises assemblages of mixed low forest of C. obesa and M. raphiophylla on the levees; assemblages of scrub of M. raphiophylla, M. hamulosa and M. uncinata on the abandonded levees; and assemblages of saltmarsh, dominantly Halosarcia spp, on the flats and depressions.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Elongate Fluviatile Delta System - Peel-Harvey inlet
Shrublands and woodlands on Muchea Limestone
EC_DESC: The community occurs on the heavy soils of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain. Where the best developed limestone occurs, near Gingin, the plant community is located on shallow black clay or sandy clay soils on limestone. Typical and common native species (from Keighery and Keighery 1995) are the tree Casuarina obesa, the mallees Eucalyptus decipiens and Eucalyptus foecunda and the shrubs Melaleuca huegelii, Alyogyne huegelii var. huegelii, Grevillea curviloba ssp. incurva, Grevillea curviloba ssp. curviloba, Grevillea evanescens, Melaleuca acerosa, Melaleuca huegelii, and the herb Thysanotus arenarius. The following exotic species are also currently common; Hypochaeris glabra, Sonchus asper, Briza maxima, Briza minor, Anagallis arvensis and Centaurium erythraea.
EC_KNOWNOCC_CAT: Less than or equal to 20 (does not meet IUCN location criteria)

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Shrublands and woodlands on Muchea Limestone
Shrublands and woodlands on Muchea Limestone
EC_DESC: The community occurs on the heavy soils of the eastern side of the Swan Coastal Plain. Where the best developed limestone occurs, near Gingin, the plant community is located on shallow black clay or sandy clay soils on limestone. Typical and common native species (from Keighery and Keighery 1995) are the tree Casuarina obesa, the mallees Eucalyptus decipiens and Eucalyptus foecunda and the shrubs Melaleuca huegelii, Alyogyne huegelii var. huegelii, Grevillea curviloba ssp. incurva, Grevillea curviloba ssp. curviloba, Grevillea evanescens, Melaleuca acerosa, Melaleuca huegelii, and the herb Thysanotus arenarius. The following exotic species are also currently common; Hypochaeris glabra, Sonchus asper, Briza maxima, Briza minor, Anagallis arvensis and Centaurium erythraea.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Perth to Gingin Ironstone Association
Perth to Gingin Ironstone Association
Shrublands on calcareous silts of the Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: This species-rich community is known from calcareous silt flat in Yalgorup National Park and a much smaller area near Bunbury. The community consists of open low scrubs with rich annual flora. Common taxa are Acacia saligna (suckering form), Leptomeria lehmannii (a taxon apparently restricted to this community type), Xanthorrhoea preissii, Gahnia trifida and Melaleuca teretifolia. The habitat of this community would be classified as a dampland. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 18’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Melaleuca huegelii - Melaleuca acerosa (currently M. systena) shrublands on limestone ridges (Gibson et al. 1994 type 26a)
EC_DESC: This community comprises species-rich thickets, heaths or scrubs dominated by Melaleuca huegelii, M. systena or Dryandra sessilis over Acacia lasiocarpa and Spyridium globulosum. A suite of herbs commonly occur under the shrub layer. This community type occurs on skeletal soils on ridge slopes and ridge tops and is known from massive limestone ridges around Yanchep north of Perth, and south of Perth near Lake Clifton. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 26a’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Coastal shrublands on shallow sands
Acacia shrublands on taller dunes
EC_DESC: Community is dominated by Acacia shrublands or mixed heaths of the larger dunes. This community stretches from Seabird to south of Mandurah. Average species richness was 35.6 species/plot and weed frequency was significantly lower at 3.4 species/plot. No consistent dominant but species such as Acacia rostellifera, Acacia lasiocarpa, Melaleuca acerosa were important.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Southern wet shrublands, Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: Shrublands or open woodlands restricted to small remnants. These occur on seasonally inundated sandy clay soils. The wetter nature of this community is apparent with the occurrence of species such as Kingia australis, Eutaxia virgata and Calothamnus lateralis. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 2’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

Wooded wetlands which support colonial waterbird nesting areas
EC_DESC: Chandala, Booragoon Lake, unnamed wetland near Pinjarra, McCarleys Swamp. This type differs from the listed ‘Perched wetlands of the Wheatbelt region with extensive stands of Casuarina obesa and Melaleuca strobophylla’ (‘Toolibin-type’ wetlands) in that the Wheatbelt type is Casuarina, rather than Melaleuca dominated. Also, Toolobin Lake type is now brackish-saline (formerly fresh-brackish), whereas this type are currently fresh-brackish.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Forests and woodlands of deep seasonal wetlands of the Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: This community occurs on alluvial sediments on sites that are inundated for long periods, resulting in more typical aquatic and deep wetland species. It is dominated by Melaleuca rhaphiophylla or Casuarina obesa. Other common species include Melaleuca teretifolia, Atriplex cinerea, Samolus repens, Sarcocornia quinqueflora and Sporobolus virginicus. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 15’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

EC_DESC: Sedgelands in Holocene dune swales of the southern Swan Coastal Plain (Gibson et al. (1994). Central Northern Darling Scarp Granite Shrubland Community
EC_DESC: Shrublands and heath on deeper loams and red earths on fragmented granite/quartzite. Heath species typically consist of the taller shrubs Xanthorrhoea acanthostachya and Allocasuarina humilis over smaller proteaceous and myrtaceous shrubs, namely Melaleuca aff. scabra, Baeckea camphorosmae and to a lesser extent, the proteaceous shrubs Dryandra armata, Hakea incrassata and Hakea undulata. Located in central region of the Northern Darling Scarp near Perth.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Mount Saddleback
Eucalyptus calophylla woodlands on heavy soils of the southern Swan Coastal Plain
EC_DESC: This community occurs on heavy soils of the eastern coastal plain and consists largely of Corymbia calophylla forests and woodlands of bushland remnants south of Capel. Typical and common native species include the shrubs Acacia extensa, Gompholobium polymorphum, Billardiera variifolia, Hibbertia hypericoides and Scaevola calliptera, and the herbs Agrostocrinum scabrum, Austrostipa semibarbata and Lomandra purpurea. The community is otherwise known as ‘community type 1b’ as defined in Gibson et al. (1994).

Depot Springs stygofauna community
EC_DESC:
The Depot Springs groundwater calcrete occurs between Sandstone and Leinster and contains an assemblage of stygofaunal species not known from anywhere else.  This unique stygofaunal assemblage includes the following:
(a) apparently restricted species
Dytiscidae
Nirridessus "fridaywellensis" sp. nov. Watts and Humphreys in press (Bidessini)
"Nirripirti hinzeae" gen. et sp. nov. Watts and Humphreys in press (Hydroporini)
The dytiscid species are known only from the Depot Springs calcrete, the latter only from Friday Well and which belongs to a different tribe (Hydroporini)(Watts and Humphreys,  in press.). These differences are supported by mtDNA analysis (Hinze et al., 2001).
(b) other fauna
 From Friday Well itself:
Ostracoda (Ryocypris n. sp., Plesiocypridopsis n. sp., Candonopsis n. sp. 1) (I. Karanovic, pers. comm. 2001).
Cyclopoida: Halicyclops n. sp. 2,  Apocyclops n. sp. 1, Metacyclops n. sp. 1,  Harpacticoida: New genus  sp. 1 (Canthocamptidae) (T. Karanovic, pers. comm. 2001).
From Depot Springs aquifer
Ostracoda (Ryocypris n. sp., Plesiocypridopsis n. sp., Candonopsis n. sp. 1) (I. Karanovic, pers. comm. 2001).
 Cyclopoida: Halicyclops n. sp. 2, Halicyclops n. sp. 3,  Apocyclops n. sp. 1, Metacyclops n. sp. 1, Metacyclops n. sp. 3, Allocyclops n. sp. 2, Harpacticoida: New genus  sp. 1 (Canthocamptidae),  Schizopera  n. sp. 1 (Diosaccidae), Parastenocaris n.  sp. 1 (Parastenocarididae) (T. Karanovic, pers. comm. 2001).
Amphipoda of unknown status.
Bathynellacea of unknown status.

EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Expert opinion
