EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Proteaceae Dominated Kwongkan Shrublands of the Southeast Coastal Floristic Province of Western Australia
EC_DESC: Consists of predominantly obligate seeding proteaceous shrubland and heath (kwongkan) and mallee heath on sandplain, duplex sand/clay and gravels overlying Eocene sediments, quartzite, schist, Yilgarn and Albany Fraser granite and greenstone ranges. Its flora is characterised by high species diversity and a high degree of endemism, particularly in the Stirling Range, Fitzgerald River National Park, Ravensthorpe Range and Russell Ranges. Due to the high levels of endemism, there are few species that exist across the entire range of the dense, obligate seeding Proteaceae dominated shrublands and kwongan of the Esperance Sandplains, however particular species have been identified as common dominant species in each of its ecodistricts.

EC_DESC: Consists of predominantly obligate seeding proteaceous shrubland and heath (kwongkan) and mallee heath on sandplain, duplex sand/clay and gravels overlying Eocene sediments, quartzite, schist, Yilgarn and Albany Fraser granite and greenstone ranges. Its flora is characterised by high species diversity and a high degree of endemism, particularly in the Stirling Range, Fitzgerald River National Park, Ravensthorpe Range and Russell Ranges. Due to the high levels of endemism, there are few species that exist across the entire range of the dense, obligate seeding Proteaceae dominated shrublands and kwongan of the Esperance Sandplains, however particular species have been identified as common dominant species in each of its ecodistricts.

Subtropical and Temperate Coastal Saltmarsh
EC_DESC: Consists of the assemblage of plants, animals and micro-organisms associated with saltmarsh in coastal regions of sub-tropical and temperate Australia (south of 23o S latitude). The habitat is coastal areas under tidal influence. In southern latitudes saltmarsh are the dominant habitat in the intertidal zone and often occur in association with estuaries. It is typically restricted to the upper intertidal environment, generally between the elevation of the mean high tide, and the mean spring tide. The community consists mainly of salt-tolerant vegetation (halophytes) including: grasses, herbs, reeds, sedges and shrubs. Succulent herbs and grasses generally dominate and vegetation is generally <0.5m tall with the exception of some reeds and sedges. Many species of non-vascular plants are also found in saltmarsh, including epiphytic algae, diatoms and cyanobacterial mats. Saltmarsh consists of many vascular plant species but is dominated by relatively few families. There is also typically a high degree of endemism at the species level. The two most widely represented coastal saltmarsh plant families are the Chenopodiaceae and Poaceae. Four structural saltmarsh forms are currently recognised based on dominance of a particular vegetation type: • dominance by succulent shrubs (e.g. Tecticornia) • dominance by grasses (e.g. Sporobolus virginicus) • dominance by sedges and grasses (e.g. Juncus kraussii, Gahnia trifida) • dominance by herbs (e.g. low-growing creeping plants such as Wilsonia backhousei, Samolus repens, Schoenus nitens).

EC_NOTES2: AB: further resultion required for occurrences where there is no longer connected to the ocean as a result of fill for roads and/or drains, or we are not sure if they are still connected. I personally do not think that this connection to the ocean should matter (well at least for our region) as the salt marsh ecosystem appears to be still functioning with apparently healthy saltmarsh vegetation, I don’t know if that is a function of the level of soil salinity which is able to maintain the community with only fresh water (rainfall,surface flow) input or if it is a reflection of underlying groundwater salinity/saltwater intrusion.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Subtropical and Temperate Coastal Saltmarsh
Subtropical and Temperate Coastal Saltmarsh
EC_DESC: Consists of the assemblage of plants, animals and micro-organisms associated with saltmarsh in coastal regions of sub-tropical and temperate Australia (south of 23o S latitude). The habitat is coastal areas under tidal influence. In southern latitudes saltmarsh are the dominant habitat in the intertidal zone and often occur in association with estuaries. It is typically restricted to the upper intertidal environment, generally between the elevation of the mean high tide, and the mean spring tide. The community consists mainly of salt-tolerant vegetation (halophytes) including: grasses, herbs, reeds, sedges and shrubs. Succulent herbs and grasses generally dominate and vegetation is generally <0.5m tall with the exception of some reeds and sedges. Many species of non-vascular plants are also found in saltmarsh, including epiphytic algae, diatoms and cyanobacterial mats. Saltmarsh consists of many vascular plant species but is dominated by relatively few families. There is also typically a high degree of endemism at the species level. The two most widely represented coastal saltmarsh plant families are the Chenopodiaceae and Poaceae. Four structural saltmarsh forms are currently recognised based on dominance of a particular vegetation type: • dominance by succulent shrubs (e.g. Tecticornia) • dominance by grasses (e.g. Sporobolus virginicus) • dominance by sedges and grasses (e.g. Juncus kraussii, Gahnia trifida) • dominance by herbs (e.g. low-growing creeping plants such as Wilsonia backhousei, Samolus repens, Schoenus nitens).

EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: S&C + South West (KW + AW) + Swan (GB): much of the community is in a degraded state due to ongoing threats - altered hydrology & drainage, clearing for urban development, poor water quality (nutrient enrichment) and climate change. Current condition is extremely variable across occurrences and occurrences have not yet been well defined. Occurrences incolude Peel Harvey Estuary, Bunbury area, Vass-Wonnerup wetlands and Quindalp.
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: S&C + South West (KW + AW) + Swan (GB): much of the community is in a degraded state due to ongoing threats - clearing for urban development, grazing by stock, weed invasion, frequent fires and climate change driving changes to assemblage. Current condition is extremely variable across occurrences and occurrences have not yet been well defined. Occurrences incolude Peel Harvey Estuary, Bunbury area, Vass-Wonnerup wetlands and Quindalp.
EC_TENURE: numerous
EC_NOTES1: AB+AW: provided updated mapping to S&C.

EC_NOTES2: AB: further resultion required for occurrences where there is no longer connected to the ocean as a result of fill for roads and/or drains, or we are not sure if they are still connected. I personally do not think that this connection to the ocean should matter (well at least for our region) as the salt marsh ecosystem appears to be still functioning with apparently healthy saltmarsh vegetation, I don’t know if that is a function of the level of soil salinity which is able to maintain the community with only fresh water (rainfall,surface flow) input or if it is a reflection of underlying groundwater salinity/saltwater intrusion.

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Ridge Road Quartzite community

EC_NOTES1: S&C: Notes from Roger Hearn 2006 - targetted for granite mining, form a different ecological community to Barrens and other south coast communitiess. Collect moisture from atmosphere. EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Porongurup Range Karri Forest
EC_DESC: Occurs on granite, red clay-loam on the mid-upper slopes of the Porongurup Range. Dominants include Eucalyptus diversicolor, Corymbia calophylla, Trymalium floribundum, Hydrocotyle ?hirta, Tetrarrhena laevis, Clematis pubescens, Lepidosperma effusum and Pteridium esculentum. Other associated species include; Apium prostratum subsp. phillipii (DRF), Ranunculus colonorum, Adiantum aethiopicum, Asplenium flabellifolium, A. aethiopicum (P4), Veronica plebeia, Poa porphyroclados and Oxalis corniculata.

EC_NOTES2: Gavan Mullen: Current mining for the colourful agate mookaite is not water use intensive. As an example, the groundwater allocation from the Dept of Water for one of the three miners at the site is 2 kilolitres. The main issue is changes to the surface water hydrology from the extraction of rock adjacent to the Mooka creek - estimated  to be on average, 500-1500 tonnes annually).

EC_COMMUNITYNAME: Hypersaline microbial community number 2
EC_DESC: Hypersaline tidal stromatolite aragonite community formed by trapping and binding by a variety of cyanobacteria and eukaryotes
EC_KNOWNOCC_NUMRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_KNOWNOCC_TREND: Static (no change)
EC_KNOWNOCC_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_AOOAREA_CAT: < 100,000ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for EN)
EC_AOOAREA_NOTES: S&C: area calc; Midwest Region: no change to area of occupancy since 2002.
EC_DEGABIOTIC_RELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_DEGABIOTIC_NOTES: Midwest Region: water quality: runoff from surrounding area, floods, sedimentation, climate change. Visitor access, scientific take, recreation = very little impact in last 10 years. Localised sedimention = one or two streams, ephemeral, small impacts in last 10 years. Wooramel River flooding = very little change in last 10 years. Condition improving due to management of access but threats Worsening condition in severity over last 10 years.
EC_DEGBIOTIC_RELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
EC_DEGBIOTIC_NOTES: Midwest Region: changes to seagrass meadows affects salinty of water, change from temperate to tropical seagrass species due to water temp (climate change). Condition improving due to management of access but threats Worsening condition in severity over last 10 years.
EC_LISTINGREASON: P1 - generally ? 5 occurrences or AOO ? 100 ha, occurrences under threat
EC_TENURE: DEC managed land - reserves IUCN I-IV, DEC managed land - reserves IUCN V-VI, DEC managed land - proposed for conservation
EC_NOTES1: Midwest Region: Shark Bay Marine Reserve Management Plan 1996
EC_PASTPRESSURES_SPECIFY: increased extreme events, flooding of Wooramel River
EC_FUTURETHREATS_SPECIFY: increased extreme events, flooding of Wooramel River
